ami:document.ami:content:
DUBLIN, April 1, 2021 /PRNewswire/ -- The "Asia's Waste-to-Energy (WtE) Market to 2026 - Stressed Landfills Boosting Growth Opportunities" report has been added to ResearchAndMarkets.com's offering.
This study looks into the WtE market in Asia, with a particular focus on waste incinerators and gasifiers. The main countries/regions covered in this study are China, India, East Asia (Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan), and Southeast Asia (Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines).
This study calculates the total and regional Asian market for WtE in 2019 and forecasts it to 2026. This study also calculates and forecasts the market for incineration and gasification systems. The markets have been shown in terms of CapEx revenues as well as in terms of new WtE projects. The study talks about the various drivers and restraints that affect the market in Asia, and also points out the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on the market.
The study looks into the key competitors in the market across the region and estimates their market shares. Some of the companies mentioned in this study include the Hitachi Zosen Corporation, China Everbright International, Keppel Seghers, CNIM Martin, Veolia, and Suez.
Finally, the study provides a detailed list of growth opportunities in the market, including advanced digital solutions, the integration of WtE with other circular economy elements, and some improved business models for WtE companies to explore.
Market Insights
Asia's large population and rapid urbanization have led to vast amounts of municipal solid waste (MSW) generation. Estimated at more than one million tonnes per day, MSW generation in urban Asia is only expected to increase in the coming years. Managing this waste is becoming a problem, with landfilling fast fading as a viable option, since land availability is decreasing and the landfills are filling up much before their intended active lifespans. Waste-to-energy (WtE), or energy-from-waste (EfW) as it is also commonly called, is a means of waste management that burns unrecyclable waste and converts it into electricity and heat for further use. It is generally used in cities to convert municipal solid waste into electricity and district heating. The residues generated from WtE are generally sent to landfills and account for more than a 95% volume reduction to them. Nowadays, WtE companies are also finding new uses of these residues to try to ensure that almost no waste goes to landfills. This also acts as an additional source of income. A circular economy works on the premise that virtually no waste moves out of the current system (no landfilling ideally) and all end-of-life products are reused, repurposed, recycled or have their energy recovered. This principle is gaining greater acceptance in Asia, with countries like Japan, China, India, and Singapore developing their own strategies in order to transition into a circular economy. Many of them are also seeing WtE as their main way of energy recovery from unrecyclable waste.
Key Topics Covered:
1. Strategic Imperatives
- Why Is It Increasingly Difficult to Grow? - The Strategic Imperative - The Impact of the Top Three Strategic Imperatives on the WtE Industry on the Asian Market - Growth Opportunities Fuel the Growth Pipeline Engine
2. Growth Opportunity Analysis, WtE Market
- WtE Market Scope of Analysis - WtE Market Segmentation - Key Growth Metrics for the WtE Market - Major Companies in Asia's WtE Market - Growth Drivers for the WtE Market - Growth Restraints for the WtE Market - Forecast Assumptions and Methodology, WtE Market - Revenue and New Plants Forecast, WtE Market - Revenue Forecast Discussion, WtE Market - Revenue Forecast by Region, WtE Market - Percent Revenue Forecast by Region, WtE Market - Revenue Forecast Analysis by Region, WtE Market - Revenue Forecast by Product Segment, WtE Market - Revenue Forecast Analysis by Product Segment, WtE Market - Competitive Landscape and Key Companies, WtE Market - Competitive Environment, WtE Market - Market Share Analysis, WtE Market
3. Growth Opportunity Universe, WtE Market
- Growth Opportunity 1 - Improved Waste Collection and Increasing Calorific Value of Waste - Growth Opportunity 2 - Innovating and Integrating with the Circular Economy - Growth Opportunity 3 - Renovating and Upgrading Older WtE Plants - Growth Opportunity 4 - Fuel Hybridization and Co-firing - Growth Opportunity 5 - Focus on Developing Countries and Upcoming Markets - Growth Opportunity 6 - Improved Business Models - Growth Opportunity 7 - Smart City Infrastructure Projects - Growth Opportunity 8 - Integrating Gasification with the Hydrogen Fuel Cell Economy - Growth Opportunity 9 - Implementing Advanced Digital Solutions Like Internet of Things (IoT) - Growth Opportunity 10 - Improved Social Branding and Outreach
4. Appendix Companies Mentioned
- China Everbright International - CNIM Martin - Hitachi Zosen Corporation - Keppel Seghers - Suez - Veolia
For more information about this report visit https://www.researchandmarkets.com/r/l48yce

Depuis la fin novembre, des dizaines de milliers d'agriculteurs sont installÃ©s sur les routes menant Ã la capitale indienne pour manifester leur opposition aux rÃ©formes gouvernementales qui libÃ©ralisent les marchÃ©s agricoles et dont ils exigent l'abrogation pure et simple.
Ces fermiers ont traversÃ© l'hiver dans des campements de fortune par un froid glacial, avec le soutien d'une multitude de villages des Etats du nord de l'Inde, avoisinant la capitale, et dont ils sont, pour la plupart, originaires.
"Ce mouvement agricole n'est pas seulement celui de ceux qui font le siÃ¨ge lÃ -bas", affirme Ã l'AFP Sumit Arya, 35 ans, le chef du village de Makrauli Khurd dans l'Haryana, Ã deux heures de route des principaux campements. "C'est notre mouvement Ã nous tous, habitants des zones rurales."
Chaque matin, dans ce village de 4.000 Ã¢mes, hommes et femmes se dÃ©pÃªchent d'apporter lÃ©gumes et bois dans les points de collecte.
Le mardi est dÃ©diÃ© aux dons de lait frais que les villageois transportent sur des carrioles, dans des petits pots de fer, juste aprÃ¨s la traite des vaches. Ensuite des hommes, Ã l'instar de Ajit Singh, les transvasent dans de grands bidons pour les acheminer aux manifestants.
"Nous ne pouvons pas leur donner notre temps, mais nous pouvons les approvisionner en nourriture et en eau, fournir tout ce qui leur est nÃ©cessaire en hiver", dÃ©clare Ã l'AFP le fermier de 58 ans, assis sur une meule de paille, dans une carriole.
DerriÃ¨re, quelqu'un lance un des cris de ralliement des manifestants "kisan ekta" ("Fermiers unis") et aussitÃ´t des villageois lÃ¨vent leur poing et entonnent le chant "zindabad" ("longue vie").
Leur mouvement constitue l'un des plus grands dÃ©fis auxquels le gouvernement du Premier ministre Narendra Modi a Ã©tÃ© confrontÃ© depuis son arrivÃ©e au pouvoir en 2014.
Les rÃ©formes votÃ©es en septembre autorisent les agriculteurs Ã vendre leurs productions aux acheteurs de leur choix, plutÃ´t que de se tourner exclusivement vers les marchÃ©s contrÃ´lÃ©s par l'Ãtat qui leur assurent un prix de soutien minimal (PSM) pour certaines denrÃ©es.
Nombre de petits exploitants agricoles s'estiment dÃ©sormais menacÃ©s par cette libÃ©ralisation qui, selon eux, risque de les obliger Ã brader leurs marchandises aux grandes entreprises pour les Ã©couler.
Le poids du secteur agricole est considÃ©rable, assurant la subsistance de prÃ¨s de 70% de 1,3 milliard d'habitants, et contribuant Ã environ 15% du PIB.
- "Sans cette fraternitÃ©, rien ne marche"-
Depuis le dÃ©but des manifestations, un rÃ©seau de solidaritÃ© s'est mis en place. Chaque jour des tracteurs aux carrioles chargÃ©es de bois et de vivres quittent des villages comme Makrauli Ã destination des campements aux portes de Delhi.
Des fermiers et leurs familles les accompagnent. "Deux ou trois tracteurs de notre village vont soutenir le moral" des manifestants, explique Ã l'AFP Ajay Punia, 18 ans, juchÃ© avec onze villageois, Ã¢gÃ©s de 14 Ã 65 ans, sur la carriole qui s'Ã©branle.
Le drapeau vert et jaune du syndicat des agriculteurs et les couleurs de l'Inde flottent ensemble sur le tracteur, tandis que rÃ©sonnent des chants de la rÃ©sistance paysanne.
Plus tard, le convoi est rejoint par deux chariots transportant une trentaine de personnes, des femmes pour la plupart. On se salue poing en l'air et les chants repartent de plus belle.
Le long de l'autoroute, les gens leur font signe de la main.
Parvenu au grand campement de Tikri en banlieue de Delhi, halte est faite Ã la cantine communautaire, les hommes vont s'asseoir en ligne sur un tapis oÃ¹ des femmes leur servent un curry de pois et de pommes de terre, accompagnÃ© d'un roti (galette) et d'une tasse de lait frais de Makrauli.
"Sans cette fraternitÃ©, rien ne marche. MÃªme dans notre village, diffÃ©rentes castes y participent", dit Arya. "Les gens s'engagent de plus en plus (...) Nous ne reculons pas."

ami:document.ami:summary: Un tracteur bleu Ã©lectrique, surmontÃ© d'un haut-parleur crachant ses chants militants, bat le rappel Ã travers le village de Makrauli, dans le nord de l'Inde, pour collecter des dons de lait destinÃ©s aux agriculteurs qui manifestent depuis prÃ¨s de trois mois aux portes de Delhi. "Ce mouvement agricole n'est pas seulement celui de ceux qui font le siÃ¨ge lÃ -bas", affirme Ã l'AFP Sumit Arya, 35 ans, le chef du village de Makrauli Khurd dans l'Haryana, Ã deux heures de route des principaux campements.

ami:document.ami:content:
Cette rencontre intervient Ã l'heure oÃ¹ les efforts se multiplient pour aboutir Ã un accord de paix avant le 1er mai lorsque les Etats-Unis doivent thÃ©oriquement retirer tous leurs militaires d'Afghanistan. Mais cette date a Ã©tÃ© remise en cause mercredi par le prÃ©sident Joe Biden.Â
Washington a proposÃ© aux belligÃ©rants afghans la formation d'un gouvernement de transition incluant les talibans. Cette idÃ©e, soutenue par Moscou, a pour l'instant reÃ§u un accueil peu enthousiaste de la part du pouvoir Ã Kaboul.Â
A Moscou, le co-fondateur du mouvement taliban, Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, a appelÃ© Ã laisser les Afghans "dÃ©cider de leur propre sort". "Le monde devrait prendre en compte les valeurs islamiques, l'indÃ©pendance et les intÃ©rÃªts nationaux du peuple afghan", a indiquÃ© sur Twitter un porte-parole, rÃ©sumant un discours Ã huis clos.Â
(L'Express Abo) Offre limitÃ©e. 2 mois pour 1â¬ sans engagement Je m'abonne
Le chef du conseil de rÃ©conciliation du gouvernement afghan, Abdullah Abdullah, a dÃ©clarÃ© de son cÃ´tÃ© que Kaboul souhaitait accÃ©lÃ©rer les nÃ©gociations et que "les deux parties entament leurs pourparlers et discussions dans une atmosphÃ¨re diffÃ©rente" que celle de Doha, au Qatar.Â
Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, autre membre de la dÃ©lÃ©gation du gouvernement afghan, a estimÃ© que la rencontre de jeudi Ã Moscou avait permis de sortir de l'"impasse" les nÃ©gociations avec les talibans.Â
AprÃ¨s avoir reÃ§u les diffÃ©rentes dÃ©lÃ©gations, le ministre russe des Affaires Ã©trangÃ¨res, SergueÃ¯ Lavrov, a appelÃ© Washington et les talibans Ã "rester attachÃ©s aux dispositions de l'accord" conclu par l'administration de l'ex-prÃ©sident Donald Trump en fÃ©vrier 2020 au Qatar.Â
Cet accord prÃ©voit le retrait des soldats amÃ©ricains d'ici au 1er mai 2021 en Ã©change de garanties sÃ©curitaires et d'un engagement des talibans Ã discuter avec Kaboul.Â
Mais le nouveau prÃ©sident des Etats-Unis, Joe Biden, a estimÃ© mercredi qu'il serait "difficile" de tenir ce dÃ©lai et les talibans l'ont aussitÃ´t mis en garde contre tout retard.Â
Les discussions Ã Moscou, qui se tiennent en prÃ©sence d'Ã©missaires pakistanais, chinois et amÃ©ricain, sont organisÃ©es parallÃ¨lement Ã celles qui ont commencÃ© en septembre Ã Doha, au Qatar, et Ã celles que la Turquie veut accueillir en avril Ã Istanbul.Â
M. Lavrov a dit "regretter que les efforts dÃ©ployÃ©s pour lancer le processus politique Ã Doha n'aient pas encore donnÃ© de rÃ©sultats" et espÃ©rer que les discussions Ã Moscou "contribueront Ã crÃ©er les conditions nÃ©cessaires" Ã des progrÃ¨s.Â
Il a soulignÃ© que "dans les conditions d'une situation militaro-politique qui se dÃ©grade, de nouveaux retards sont inacceptables" pour les nÃ©gociations Ã Doha.Â
Les violences se sont intensifiÃ©es ces derniers mois dans tout l'Afghanistan, malgrÃ© les pourparlers. Dans ce contexte, le dÃ©part des Etats-Unis inquiÃ¨te le gouvernement en place Ã Kaboul, dont l'autoritÃ© est contestÃ©e ou mise Ã mal sur plus de la moitiÃ© du territoire.Â

Dans ce contexte, le dÃ©part des Etats-Unis inquiÃ¨te le gouvernement en place Ã Kaboul, dont l'autoritÃ© est contestÃ©e ou mise Ã mal sur plus de la moitiÃ© du territoire.

ami:document.ami:content:
User experience design is highly dynamic, echoing uncertainty and value conflict in the problematic experiences in which we designers engage in. Our design inquiries are often through lived experiences, and for that reason, our role and responsibilities are critical to design. Our engagement determines the nature of the problemâs resolution but also explores the nature of the problem.
A fully understood problem is only as good as the designers interpreting it. To simply say that we are purposefully finding the user needs is a simplification. Peopleâs thoughts, actions, and their problematic experience breathe within the frame of its situation.
We should, to the extent possible, experience and describe the situation that is being designed for as it may only be understood in its own larger frame. To interpret or empathise/sense with problematic situations that are foreign to us. To tell the untold. And to discover and articulate desires and tensions that are unresolved or unfulfilled.
(Person holding clear martini glass with the word SENSE overlaying the photo) (Person holding clear martini glass with the word SENSE overlaying the photo) (Person holding clear martini glass with the word SENSE overlaying the photo) Photo by Amy Shamblen on Unsplash Peopleâs problems and desires are often not directly apparent to us in our inquiries. Such problems hold dimensions that can not simply be comprehensible through linear steps of methods and activities.
They are unstable and unique, often wicked imbued with implicit meanings, which require us to be more. To encompass a reflective practice and critical thinking in order to interpret those meanings through participation, observations, interviews, documents, etc.
It is often other peopleâs problems that we work with and therefore we have to explore and understand people, situations, places, practices that we are not familiar with. This is why we engage in lived experiences, or situations, where peopleâs problems reside, to live their world.
How people interact can offer more insight than how they account for it. From this perspective, we are embodied inquiries explicating peopleâs experiences and their implicit meanings.
(Yellow painted wall with the word WHO overlaying the photo) (Yellow painted wall with the word WHO overlaying the photo) (Yellow painted wall with the word WHO overlaying the photo) Photo by Janita Sumeiko on Unsplash We are embodied inquirers who delve into the present in order to design for the future. And often only through engagement may we fully understand the problem and the world in which it arises, shaping it and rendering it meaningful.
Here, we are not spectators but designers who experiment in a continuum between knowing and doing and are therefore dependent on critical thinking and interpretation. This hands-on interaction with first-hand accounts of experiences, back and forth, fuels our design process to attempt one framing and reframing after another.
The whys, hows, and whats We interpret through critical thinking. Whilst critical thinking brings intention, motivation, and rationale for the unfolding of our inquiry, our design intentions are supported by reflection on the whyâs and howâs. We can think of it as explicating or unpacking.
What is said, or done, and the experiences that are imbued with deeper meanings. Why? How? What?
Critical thinking allows us to pose thoughtful questions, elicit a fruitful response and design organically. It provides reasoning and arguments for our design choices and widens our understanding, seeking as much precision as the situation requires.
Such acts often uncover further tensions and uncertainties which form the basis of new questions to purposefully resolve. These questions tend to draw us closer to the future experience, the intended use situation.
(Pile of French macaroons with the word WHY overlaying the photo) (Pile of French macaroons with the word WHY overlaying the photo) (Pile of French macaroons with the word WHY overlaying the photo) Photo by Keila HÃ¶tzel on Unsplash One part of critical thinking is asking for clarification and/or challenging questions. Not succumb to uninterpreted findings but questioning them to gain richer understandings of the situation which allows us to rethink our evaluation criteria.
Why is the person expressing a particular tension? What does the particular tension mean? What would be an example? What would not be an example? How does this? How so? What is the person not telling us? What are the underlying meanings? What is actually being expressed? Why, why, and why?
This constant critical thinking and reflection shaping us toward particular outcomes is what moves the situation from multiple possibilities toward a set of actual possibilities. Careful and mindful actions allow us to determine which ends should be achieved and which should be discouraged.

ami:document.ami:content:
"Nous faisons nos adieux Ã notre leader", a dÃ©clarÃ© le prÃ©sident Ramaphosa, se souvenant de Zwelithini comme d'un "dÃ©fenseur acharnÃ© de son peuple" qui "apprÃ©ciait la diversitÃ©" et respectait les autres cultures. "C'est un jour difficile car un grand arbre est tombÃ©".Â
- Mort du Covid? - Le chef de l'Etat a laissÃ© entendre que le roi Zwelithini luttait contre le Covid-19 au moment de sa mort.Â
"Notre leader et roi bien-aimÃ©... a succombÃ© Ã la maladie mortelle qui a emportÃ© la vie de tant de personnes", a-t-il dit, sans nommer le virus.Â
Pendant tout son discours, M. Ramaphosa est passÃ© de l'anglais au zoulou, rendant ainsi hommage Ã la langue la plus rÃ©pandue parmi la douzaine de langues officielles de l'Afrique du Sud. Il y a plus de 11 millions de Zoulous en Afrique du Sud, soit prÃ¨s d'un cinquiÃ¨me de la population du pays.Â
Parmi les invitÃ©s figuraient notamment l'ancien prÃ©sident Jacob Zuma, membre de l'ethnie zouloue, le prÃ©sident nouvellement Ã©lu de la ConfÃ©dÃ©ration africaine de football Patrice Motsepe et la princesse CharlÃ¨ne de Monaco,installÃ©s sur des chaises Ã bonne distance les unes des autres, afin de respecter les mesures sanitaires en vigueur.Â
Les six Ã©pouses du roi Ã©taient installÃ©es au premier rang, des voiles de dentelle noire recouvrant leurs tÃªtes.Â
Le roi a Ã©tÃ© "plantÃ©" dans la terre dans la nuit, au cours d'une cÃ©rÃ©monie intime.Â
Alors que le pays est affectÃ© depuis une semaine par des coupures d'Ã©lectricitÃ© quotidiennes, d'une durÃ©e de plusieurs heures, la compagnie Eskom a annoncÃ©, dans un communiquÃ© mercredi soir, que l'Ã©lectricitÃ© serait maintenue jeudi de 10h Ã 14h, afin que tous les Sud-Africains puissent regarder la cÃ©rÃ©monie d'obsÃ¨ques Ã la tÃ©lÃ©vision et porter "le deuil du roi".Â
TÃ´t dans la matinÃ©e, des groupes de dizaines de jeunes femmes, en tenue traditionnelle, mini-jupes aux couleurs vives, seins nus et masquÃ©es, ont chantÃ© et dansÃ© devant le palais royal zoulou. Â
Elles ont dÃ©roulÃ© une banderole proclamant "Longue vie Ã Sa MajestÃ©". Les hommes, en tenue de guerriers - peaux de lÃ©opard recouvrant leur torse, bandeau, boucliers et lance en main, ont dansÃ© aussi, levant haut la jambe pour frapper Ã terre, selon la tradition zouloue.Â
Descendant du lÃ©gendaire Chaka, fondateur du royaume au dÃ©but du XIXe siÃ¨cle, Goodwill Zwelithini, 8e roi des Zoulous, a rÃ©gnÃ© pendant 50 ans.Â
Aussi vÃ©nÃ©rÃ© que controversÃ©, Goodwill Zwelithini Ã©tait notamment connu Ã l'Ã©tranger pour ses propos outranciers sur les migrants, les homosexuels, ou pour avoir rÃ©tabli dans les annÃ©es 1980 l'Umhlanga, une danse annuelle de jeunes vierges aux seins nus.Â
"Il l'a fait par amour", explique Nhlanhla Magwaza, 24 ans, l'une de ces "jeunes filles", venue de la ville voisine d'Ulundi pour lui rendre hommage.Â
Zwelithini a Ã©tÃ© Ã©galement accusÃ© d'avoir fait le jeu du systÃ¨me d'apartheid, au crÃ©puscule de la domination de la minoritÃ© blanche dans les annÃ©es 1990, en luttant contre l'African National Congress (ANC) de Nelson Mandela, alors interdit par les autoritÃ©s.Â
En tant que chef traditionnel particuliÃ¨rement influent, il a conseillÃ© les lÃ©gislateurs et rencontrÃ© des hommes politiques puissants tout au long de son rÃ¨gne.Â
Charismatique et Ã la langue acÃ©rÃ©e, le roi a Ã©tÃ© aussi louÃ© pour avoir dissipÃ© certaines dangereuses lÃ©gendes et fables entourant le VIH/sida, dans un pays alors frappÃ© de plein fouet par cette Ã©pidÃ©mie.Â
Le nom de son successeur reste pour l'instant inconnu. Il aurait dÃ» Ãªtre normalement remplacÃ© par le fils aÃ®nÃ© de la premiÃ¨re de ses Ã©pouses, avec laquelle il a eu 28 enfants. Mais ce premier fils a Ã©tÃ© assassinÃ© en novembre dernier Ã l'Ã¢ge de 50 ans dans sa maison de Johannesburg.Â
Selon l'historien local Khaya Ndwandwe, la dÃ©signation d'un successeur pourrait prendre deux ans. "Il y a certains rituels qui doivent Ãªtre accomplis", a-t-il expliquÃ©, notamment la "purification" des Ã©pouses et du palais, ainsi que l'abattage du bÃ©tail.Â

ami:document.ami:content:
Many design trends posts act like art directors â practically guiding your hands on the mouse. This year, weâre doing trends different, by focusing on what actually matters. From accessibility to truth, no-code to role, these are the web design trends to focus on if your definition of beauty includes functionality, accessibility, and psychological safety.
Web designâs biggest trends for 2020 Each year, I share my take on the web design trends that will shape the coming year, often incorporating the opinions of my fellow designers at Webflow, as well as those of well-known names in the broader design community. Iâve always included a mix of concrete design details and interaction models as well as higher-level concepts, which helped fill out my self-imposed constraint of adding one more trend than the number of the year (19 web design trends for 2018, for example).
This year, Iâm breaking the mold.
Because 2020 is going to be a different year for design, to my mind. A year when weâre all going to focus a little less on this layout, that color scheme, and whichever nifty animation mode caught our eye last week, and instead consider the deeper underlying concerns of design.
So Iâm ditching the same ole design specifics we see year after year (broken grids, anyone?!) to focus on the bigger picture. To ask far more significant questions like:
- How do we design to make information clear, while still making it easily consumable? - How do we make design universal, ensuring that no one feels excluded or erased by our decisions? - And, perhaps most significantly, how will a new generation of tools, built upon a paradigm thatâs simultaneously brand-new, yet old as spreadsheets, change not only the way we work, but also what we produce?
But more on that last point later. Letâs dive into the 9 web design trends weâll see in 2020:
1. Designing truth Itâs no secret that weâve entered what many are calling the âpost-truthâ era, with myriad instances of deepfakes, misinformation campaigns, and outright lies popping up, gaining viral traction, and ultimately shaping the decision-making of millions â all too often driven by prominent individuals who will here go unnamed.
The major social media platforms have each come out with policies â and in some cases, designs â to account for this new flourishing of untruths.
Facebook has decided that it simply wonât intervene with political untruths . To support its stance, the platform has cited everything from the First Amendment to the FCCâs similar stance on political advertising on the TV. Conveniently forgetting that it is neither a) the government (the one thatâs actually restricted from censorship by freedom of speech) nor b) the increasingly anachronistic technology that is television.
Facebookâs been (apparently) trying to combat fake news on its platform since 2015, doing so in classic Silicon Valley iterative design style. It first tried to encourage individual users to flag content as âfalse newsâ â an odd half-borrowing from President Trump â then by marking some stories as âdisputedâ â which, according to what it called âacademicâ research, backfired by reinforcing some usersâ belief in the content â then, most recently overlaying the content with a straightforward notice reading:
False Information
Checked by independent fact-checkers.
(Side-by-side comparison of how Facebook and Instagram use an overlay to obscure âfalse informationâ) (Side-by-side comparison of how Facebook and Instagram use an overlay to obscure âfalse informationâ) (Side-by-side comparison of how Facebook and Instagram use an overlay to obscure âfalse informationâ) Source: The Verge The overlay also provides a prominent CTA to view the fact-checkersâs findings â as well as a secondary button to go ahead and view the false content.
At present, thereâs still no plan to flag paid political posts as false.
One interesting thing to note is that Facebook started trying to remedy sharing of false information only after it was shared â the original poster was given no alerts to the fact that the content they wanted to share was disputed. Theyâve amended this in subsequent designs to be more proactive in alerting the original sharer â but itâs still intriguing that the notifications focus on the fact that thereâs âadditional reportingâ on the content.
This strategy focuses on encouraging what we call âcuriosity clicks.â This encourages engagement with the information, but thatâs also its flaw: you have to care enough that thereâs âadditional reportingâ to click through. As a content designer, I have to wonder if it wouldnât be more effective to name the fact checkers and pull a significant quote on the content. Snopes, for example, does a great job of highlighting what the specific claim is and giving it a straightforward âtrueâ or âfalseâ (with a range of fuzziness between) rating.
(Screenshot of Snopes article on U.S. President Donald Trumpâs tweet of his own head on Rockyâs body. Itâs true.) (Screenshot of Snopes article on U.S. President Donald Trumpâs tweet of his own head on Rockyâs body. Itâs true.) (Screenshot of Snopes article on U.S. President Donald Trumpâs tweet of his own head on Rockyâs body. Itâs true.) Yep, he actually did do that.Twitter has taken a rather more straightforward (and cheerworthy) stance of simply disallowing political advertising on its platform. Though as many people have commented, itâs just not that easy. All kinds of misinformation âearnsâ its way into our feeds daily, a reality that Twitter seems to have done little to nothing to address.
In the end, what really matters here is not so much what the major platforms are doing to bring clarity and trustworthiness to their platforms, but what you might do to bring more of that into your own work.
Here are a few thoughts on doing that:
Label more prominently and clearly (Sponsored article section of Slateâs homepage.) (Sponsored article section of Slateâs homepage.) (Sponsored article section of Slateâs homepage.) 5 ads. Not labeled as such.In a 2016 report on a Stanford study of studentsâ ability to determine the veracity of information found online, the Wall Street Journal stated:
Some 82% of middle-schoolers couldnât distinguish between an ad labeled âsponsored contentâ and a real news story on a website, according to a Stanford University study of 7,804 students from middle school through college.
Much of the âoptimizationâ of ad formats like âsponsored contentâ has gone into â¦ well, hiding the fact that theyâre ads. Just look at the name: âsponsored content.â On a content-driven site, that simply implies that the content was âsponsoredâ by someone, much as race car drivers are sponsored by various corporations.
The reality, of course, is that these are ads, even if theyâre not as direct as banners. And we should label them as such.
And itâs not just our language that could be clearer. Our design work could use some improvements too. Just look at the screenshot above (taken on Dec 3, 2019). Every single story in that shot is a piece of sponsored content, hosted on a different website, but seamlessly integrated into Slateâs own homepage.
(News & Politics section of Slateâs homepage) (News & Politics section of Slateâs homepage) (News & Politics section of Slateâs homepage) Compare the labeling of this âreal newsâ section to that on the sponsored content section above.The title font for the native news articles and the sponsored stories is the same. But note whatâs quite different: the font size and location of the âauthor.â In the native stories, the authorâs name is set reasonably large, above the title. You definitely still see the title first, but the author name cries out for your attention in these real stories.
The sponsored posts, on the other hand? The âauthorâ â or brand, actually â is set much smaller. The fact that the âauthorâ is listed as a brand, rather than as an individual writing for the brand, is telling as well: While we have someone to follow up with (or blame or praise) for real reporting, the sponsored stories are attributed to faceless brands.
Perhaps even more significantly: note that the real articles are practically emblazoned with a category title (e.g., News & Politics). The sponsored stories? Oddly lacking that prominent header.
Make sources more obvious In the world of journalism, youâll often hear the mantra:
Consider the source.
Which is not something most students do these days, according to the study:
Many students judged the credibility of newsy tweets based on how much detail they contained or whether a large photo was attached, rather than on the source.
And while that maxim is stressed to young and aspiring journos as a core practice, it could also help us designers help the rest of the world out. What if, for example, every organizationâs Twitter profile included a link to their Wikipedia page, or a Google search of their name? What if publications featured an about page that clarified their political stance, history, management, and funding sources? One better: what if they linked to independent commentators on the publication?
These, of course, are just ideas â if nothing else, prompts to consider more deeply how we might encourage readers to act more like journalists and consider their sources in a more objective manner.
But we can also consider carefully the criteria young students are using to evaluate credibility, and encourage our social media teams to make updates information-dense, and pair them with large, engaging graphics.
Finally, and to bring this closer to home for web designers crafting publishing experiences (that is, any designer who works on a site with a blog, case studies, etc.): consider making your authors and their credentials much more obvious in your content-driven experiences. This can not only boost your siteâs credibility and give readers a point of contact, but also arm readers to better evaluate your authorsâ content. A thoughtfully curated list of contributors then becomes a marketing asset, akin to the list of blurbs on every mass-market book cover.
Use ârelated contentâ to provide context and contrast Related content â a familiar content pattern often appearing in the middle or at the end of blog posts and news articles, often under a heading like âYou might also likeâ¦â â gives designers a powerful tool for adding easily accessible nuance to a readerâs understanding of a topic.
How? By ensuring two things:
- That opinion pieces are contextualized by the stories they comment on, or by contrasting opinions - That news stories get additional color through the opinion pieces through the pieces that comment on them
Using related content to provide extra context on fact- and opinion-based pieces helps work against our ageâs increasingly obvious preference for âbite-sizedâ information. Bite-sized data helps us quickly get a basic understanding of issues in a world fraught with issues â but it also means that we often lack a nuanced understanding of said issues.
When we rely solely on our favorite âinfluencersââ hot-takes on Twitter, we start to look a lot like a pitchfork-and-torch wielding mob, all too ready to take one charismatic voice for the font of truth. But the more that content creators and designers can point readers to extra information and contrasting opinions, the more we can encourage nuanced understandings that rely more on information and reason than on emotion.
- Label your content types clearly to help readers create a mental model of your content and better distinguish between organic and promotional materials - Contextualize and promote your sources so readers know where your content comes from and can better evaluate its credibility - Use related content to add context and promote nuanced understandings of topics
All the above said, itâs worth remembering that misinformation isnât a fixed target, a fact captured beautifully by Tom Rosenstiel, director of the American Press Institute and senior fellow at the Brookings Institution:
Whatever changes platform companies make, and whatever innovations fact checkers and other journalists put in place, those who want to deceive will adapt to them. Misinformation is not like a plumbing problem you fix. It is a social condition, like crime, that you must constantly monitor and adjust to. Since as far back as the era of radio and before, as Winston Churchill said, âA lie can go around the world before the truth gets its pants on.â
Which is to say: if you want to play a role in fighting misinformation in 2020, prepare for the long haul, and be ready to update your strategies and tactics as the information landscape continues to change.
2. Accessibility is (finally) key Before I dive in here, I have to offer a confession on behalf of Webflow: We did not build Webflow with accessibility in mind. But weâve recently hired two accessibility specialists and formed a team around the effort to make accessibility a first-class citizen in Webflow. Stay tuned for more on that.
Web accessibility â the practice of ensuring that websites and web applications are usable by everyone, regardless of their abilities â has long been a vital part of the web design and development process in mature organizations. Particularly in governmental and publicly funded institutions, where Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) compliance has long been a legal requirement.
But with high-profile cases like the Dominoâs lawsuit and others gaining broad notice, the writing is on the wall: soon, all websites will be required to meet ADA requirements â making accessibility a compliance issue, not just a ânice to have.â
And while I donât want to overplay the impact this will have on our profession â as numerous relatively minor interventions in our processes and skillsets will have significant impact on the accessibility of our products â I donât think we can afford to underplay this fact either. Because while relatively small efforts will have significant impact, the changes required of us to make more accessible sites will affect literally every step of the design process, and the workflows of every participant in that process.
Donât believe me? Check out Voxâs accessibility checklist , which outlines the ways every web professional, from designers to QAs to editors, can contribute to building more accessible websites and applications.
But the work of accessibility requires far more than checklists and automated checks via browser plugins. Because much of the work of accessible website design canât be checked via software. And because web design, outside of web app development, is essentially all about publishing, accessible web design means reconsidering the ways we publish too. If we create videos for the web, we need to consider captioning, transcripts, and other non-visual equivalents we can offer. If we host podcasts, weâll need to think about how we can make our content available to those with low or non-existent hearing. If we publish infographics and charts, weâll need to think about how we can make the content of these mediums available to those who canât see them.
And designers, long used to relying on visual formats and low-contrast aesthetics to do their work, will have to stretch to account for this more inclusive paradigm. Weâll have to think long and hard about the limitations of visual formats not only for the differently abled, but for those for whom visuals arenât nearly as transparently legible as they are to designers (myself included!).
Blind spots abound in the design process, and these holes are often based on our disciplines. As a writer, I often find it difficult to account for those with a less broad vocabulary, as well as those who prefer visual formats. (Even the turn of phrase I opened this paragraph with could be seen as ableist.) Designers, similarly, tend to overlook the value and power of a single sentence, especially when paired with an equally powerful visual.
The reality is: we learned our skills in a context that assumed there was such a thing as a ânormal.â That you could apply your skills to communicate to âeveryoneâ in your preferred format because âmost peopleâ can process your preferred format just fine.
(Chart of permanent, temporary, and situational disabilities for sight, hearing, touch, and speech) (Chart of permanent, temporary, and situational disabilities for sight, hearing, touch, and speech) (Chart of permanent, temporary, and situational disabilities for sight, hearing, touch, and speech) Disability can be permanent, temporary, or situational. Source: Microsoft Inclusive Design But the fact is that is much as 26% of the United Statesâ population experiences some form of disability, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). And as Microsoft has so eloquently communicated via their inclusive design content, 100% of the population may experience temporary or situational disabilities. And the fact is that none of us are getting any younger, and the older we get, the higher the chance weâll experience a more or less permanent disability becomes.
There is no health; physicians say that we At best enjoy but a neutrality.
âJohn Donne, âAn Anatomy of the World,â 1611
The world (and its advertising) may turn around the healthy and young, but we can no longer afford to design solely for them.
3. Content gets its due in web and product design Iâve been a content professional working on the web since 2006, and in those (almost) 14 years, one debate has defined my experience of the profession:
Does design or content come first?
This so-called debate has never failed to flummox me, for several reasons. And itâs incredibly relieving to me to see that designers are increasingly coming to understand what has always seemed obvious to me: that the âcontent,â or rather, the âmessage,â has to come before the design. Because, otherwise, thereâs literally nothing to design.
On the other hand, this debate is confusing and frustrating because, in reality, itâs not even the real question. Neither content nor design come first. Because you really canât create content or design till you have a strategy. And you canât have a strategy until you have a goal: a purpose that the thing you want to publish should fulfill.
To clarify this, I like to point back to web design and publishingâs predecessor: print publishing. Before you can design a book, you need a book to design. And before you can write a book, you need a point: an idea or truth that you wish to convey to your audience.
Itâs important to point out here that a website is not, in fact, a book. Its material expression, functionality, and distribution are vastly different than a book. But in terms of purpose, a book and a website are very much the same: they both exist to convey information to an audience. (No, Iâm not talking about web apps here.*)
The core difference is that the website hopes to gather some information from its audience in exchange for the information (or functionality) it offers: typically, an email, that uniquely modern key to an individualâs identity, and to communication with that person.
But to get, you have to give. You need to offer some value, and even the teams behind the worldâs most popular digital products realize that quality content makes for an incredible source of value, allowing you to draw the attention of even those your product (isnât yet) for.
Of course, content isnât just blog posts. (Nor is it just words, but thatâs a whole other post.) Content also plays a key role in your productâs overall user experience, and increasingly, platforms are feeling the pain of getting content wrong.
Hereâs an example I ran across just the other day, on LinkedIn (where I once worked, for transparency):
(âIs this information correct?â modal on LinkedIn.com) (âIs this information correct?â modal on LinkedIn.com) (âIs this information correct?â modal on LinkedIn.com) Notice anything? I sure do! And I could go on and on about the flaws of this interface, but Iâll restrict myself to the single most important one:
What the heck do I do if thatâs not my âcorrectâ or âactiveâ email address?
Iâm being asked to take action on this information if necessary, but thereâs no obvious way for me to do anything but âremoveâ my phone number! The content and the interface are completely misaligned, ensuring that â at best â LinkedIn might get an accurate, current phone number from me.
But, ironically, what this UI does best for me, the user, is to remind me that LinkedIn has my phone number (why tho?!) and, better yet, give me a chance to dissociate it from my profile. (I originally wrote âdelete it from their database,â but a colleague rightly pointed out â¦ it almost certainly doesnât do that.)
Iâm just going to guess that wasnât their goal.
But Iâm not here to complain about LinkedInâs content. Iâm here to stress the centrality of content to the overall user experience of any digital environment. Hopefully the above does the trick, but to reinforce my point, here are a few content-related highs and lows from 2019:
Tone can make or break a relationship. I donât, personally, share Aliciaâs praise here. That pun on Alaska is â¦ rough. Most telling, perhaps, is the increasing prominence of content strategy and UX writing in the brands of some of todayâs most recognizable brands. Just look to the design publications and publicly-shared design systems of brands like Facebook, Dropbox, Google, and Shopify and youâll see the word content â and its dedicated creators â getting their fair share of name drops.
Facebook Design is talking about content.
So is Dropbox!
And Materialâs got some thoughts on words too.*But a content-first viewpoint still has dramatic effects on web apps: Just look at Twitter, where a single content decision â limiting character count â has done everything to define both the glory and horror of that platform.
4. Inclusivity matters We designers, for all our focus on empathy, remain human beings. We aim relentlessly to take othersâ views and experiences into account through user research, critique sessions, A/B testing, and myriad other methods. But at the end of the day, weâre all subject to a very human propensity: an unconscious assumption that what works for us will work for everyone else.
Just look at the language we use every day: Reach out. I see that. We hear you.
We assume these phrases are universal â equally meaningful to everyone who hears or reads them. We blithely conflate the concrete, sensory basis of these phrases with their emotional register and intent.
But itâs a faulty assumption. The blind cannot see that. The deaf do not hear you. Those with cerebral palsy may struggle to reach out.
Of course, inclusivity is about far more than accounting for disability. Itâs about accounting for difference. It means that we canât limit ourselves to âmaleâ and âfemaleâ when we ask someoneâs gender in a form. It means realizing that a âhappy Fatherâs day!â email wonât mean the same thing to the child of a deadbeat dad as it does to one who grew up in a ânormalâ nuclear family. Hell, it means realizing that even the one from the ânormalâ family might have a bad relationship with their father â or have, not a father and a mother, but two mothers.
To enjoy and find value in a product, an individual needs to see themselves reflected within it. Without that glimpse of themselves, what a person sees instead is a refusal. The message is: you donât belong here.
Designing for inclusivity â and ultimately, for UX â then means making space for our audience within the products we build.
I want to expand on that link between inclusive design and user experience design. Because I think that inclusivity â which is ultimately the idea that we should treat âothersâ not as others, but as part of us â is built right into the very notion of user experience design, and I want to take a moment to explain why.
Letâs start by looking at Peter Morvilleâs âuser experience honeycombâ:
(The user experience honeycomb by Peter Morville) (The user experience honeycomb by Peter Morville) (The user experience honeycomb by Peter Morville) The user experience honeycomb.The honeycomb aims to depict the interlinked characteristics that form a user experience â good or bad. The overall user experience is a gestalt â a sum total â of all these facets, arrived at via a kind of mental math we perform automatically and without deep consideration of the individual values we might assign to one or the other.
Note that each is a characteristic in the eye of the beholder. And who the beholder is, whether âusâ or âother,â isnât part of the graph. That is: the honeycomb doesnât say who the product is credible, valuable, accessible, etc., for.
We can, of course, assume that the beholder is âour audienceâ: the group of people we most want to appeal to and turn into paying customers.*
Now, audiences may seem homogenous insofar as, for, say, a web design platform, all members of the audience are interested in designing websites. But thatâs one, relatively minor, characteristic when we look at the whole of what makes up a human being.
Within that seemingly homogeneous crowd thereâs a multitude of identities. Different races, creeds, religions, gender identities, gender expressions, socioeconomic classes, family backgrounds, cultures, and dozens of other facets of selfhood â they all want to build, manage, and grow websites.
Therefore, excluding people exhibiting any one particular flavor of any of those backgrounds poses a threat to the overall user experience. Which translates directly to a business risk â especially in the modern day, when a single tweet can mobilize massive numbers of people to either lionize or villainize a company. (Or, letâs face it: both.)
Exclusionary design, then, has a direct impact on not only the user experience, but also the bottom line.
Of course, you could argue that being inclusive poses its own business risk, in that it might alienate your more conservative users. But when you look at the size and prominence of companies that are now more than happy to take âprogressive,â inclusive stances on any number of issues â from LGBTQ+ pride to toxic masculinity, itâs pretty easy to see the writing on the wall: These businesses have done the math, and theyâve come to the conclusion that the reward of inclusivity far outweighs the risk.
I would, then, posit that the definition of user experience design should be:
The practice of designing experiences to be as useful, usable, findable, credible, accessible, desirable, and valuable as possible for any user, regardless of their identity.
When we set out to design for others, we often end up designing for ourselves. (Especially when we do so without the constraints of a framework or design system.) We can, of course, make assumptions about who weâre designing for, and more specifically, who we want to design for â but our biases still lead the way.
Itâs important to note that this isnât a recrimination. We canât avoid biased thinking because itâs been built into us from day 1 and become largely unconscious. What we can do is to work to consciously limit or overcome our biases. Thatâs what makes user research so fundamental. Without exploring the differing viewpoints, cognitive habits, and identities of our audiences, we end up designing to fit our expectations â and for every web professional, thatâs a weakness.
Writers will tend to assume that written content is the most likely to be effective. Designers will lean heavily on the visual and/or interactive. And devs and engineers â¦ well, my biases prevent me from easily filling in that blank.
Point is: when we stretch beyond our boundaries and defaults to incorporate othersâ perspectives, we strengthen our work, making it more accessible and comprehensible to others. Which makes it that much more likely to work well for everyone.
*Because, of course, UX design is, as most commonly practiced, a capitalist discipline. Capitalism being, of course, a political philosophy.
â5. The no-code revolution has arrived (Google search results page for the query âno-codeâ) (Google search results page for the query âno-codeâ) (Google search results page for the query âno-codeâ) No big deal. Just over 10 billion results.When it comes to democratizing the power of software, itâs hard to think of an industry making more of an impact.
âCaleb Kaiser, Growth at AngelList
If youâre at all aware of Webflow, you know that weâre all-in on no-code, a new way of thinking about web and software development thatâs ditching the traditional coding paradigm, in which code can only âproperlyâ be produced in a text editor, written by hand, in favor of a new visual modality.
The reasons for our enthusiasm for no-code are many, but theyâre ultimately driven by a desire to make coding accessible. Not simply so that âeveryone can code,â of course, but so that everyone can enjoy the power to bring their ideas to life.
Instead of taking the coding bootcamp or early-childhood coding education route, weâre redesigning the very way that code is made.
In other words, we believe itâs time to refactor coding itself.
You donât have to look far back in history to find analogous transformations. Just look back to the first graphical user interface (GUI) itself.
Before the first GUI, computing was keyboard-driven. The primary user interface (UI) was the terminal â a primitive text editor where computer users literally âtoldâ the computer what to do through an arcane language of commands and responses. This interface model required a great deal of knowledge of its users, meaning that truly savvy computer users were few and far between. (And yes, those of you just returning from the Thanksgiving onslaught of IT support requests from computer-illiterate family members: it was worse back then.)
This also limited computersâ applicability to real-world problems. Sure, they sprang up in all sorts of high-knowledge environments, but they were anything but the ubiquitous engines of knowledge work theyâve become today.
Then came the mouse (along with almost a dozen other game-changing technologies), introduced in whatâs now known as the âMother of All Demos.â
As the demoâs Wikipedia page puts it, this demo sparked the revolution that would transform computers from mere ânumber-crunchingâ tools into âcommunication and information retrievalâ hubs. And while it would take years for this demo to turn into a functional reality, that reality is what made computers sufficiently accessible to a sufficiently large population to make them the definitive technology of the 20th (and now 21st) century.
No-code now aims to take that sea-change a step further by empowering an even broader swath of people to not only use computers, but to build the software that makes computers so powerful, without coding it.
Today, Webflow occupies a particular niche of the no-code movement, which we call âvisual web development.â Since 2013, weâve been relentlessly focused on making the primary tools of front-end web development â HTML, CSS, and JavaScript â dramatically more accessible to dramatically more people. And weâre proud to say that, here in late 2019, weâve enabled thousands upon thousands of folks who would never have thought of themselves as web developers to build beautiful, powerful websites using technologies like CSS grid, JavaScript-controlled Lottie files, and semantic HTML5.
In 2015, we began to take that mission a step further with the launch of Webflow CMS, a GraphQL-powered database and publishing tool that gives designers and developers the power to create custom schema â then design around those data fields â visually.
Here in 2019, database management and publishing tools like Webflow CMS have become the core of all kinds of powerful web-based applications, and we couldnât be more excited to lend our voice to the continued revolution that is no-code.
Of course, weâre far from the only no-code tool out there. So weâd like to take this opportunity to shout out to our fellow travelers in the no-code future:

6. The rise of the visual developer Of course, technologies mean little without the human beings who use them.
And so, to parallel the wave of no-code tooling comes the rise of the no-code tool user, or, âvisual developer.â
Just as the desktop publishers who used tools like Microsoft Word/Publisher, Adobe InDesign, and other tools may have known little to everything about picas and PostScript, visual developers may be anything from code experts to pure novices â but theyâve learned to master the machines of translation that turn design decisions into functional code.
(LinkedIn job postings mentioning âWebflowâ) (LinkedIn job postings mentioning âWebflowâ) (LinkedIn job postings mentioning âWebflowâ) At the time of writing (December 16, 2019 â a slow time in hiring), 135 jobs mention Webflow. And weâre just one visual web development tool!In doing so, they act as force multipliers to the traditionally trained coders who have built websites and apps for decades, and continue to do so. They automate tasks that used to take tedious hours of manual work. They transform static wireframes and mockups into fully functional web experiences that not only present content to visitors, but then take in visitorâs data, pipe it into email service providers and customer databases, and nurture them into leads and, ultimately, paying customers.
And most concretely, in modern web design workflows, they enable brand, growth, and marketing teams to move much, much faster. In one dramatic example, they turn the website update cycle from an 8-year process into an 8-minute one, as car-sharing startup Getaroundâs Camille Esposito told us in her No Code Conf talk, âTaking back your website.â
As the no-code landscape becomes more and more mature and powerful, we expect to see âvisual developerâ becoming as common a sight in job postings as âweb developerâ and âweb designerâ are now â and in the latter case, we can honestly see âvisual developerâ taking their place entirely.
7. Design has its seat at the table. Now what? Ever heard the phrase âcareful what you wish forâ?
Design has been pushing for a so-called âseat at the tableâ â that is, a voice in higher-level decision-making at companies â for years now. And increasingly, weâre seeing that happen. At least, according to the zeitgeist. Every day, more and more articles suggest that design is the key differentiator at [insert hot startup name here]. Design-focused content seems to be gaining more and more prominence in popular culture, with documentary series like Abstract popping up in watercooler conversations almost as often as [insert whatever the kids are watching these days here]. Every time I grab a seat in a cafe, the word âUXâ resounds around the room at least half a dozen times every hour â granted, I live in the heart of UX country, but still.
And yet, how much traction has design really gained in the top echelons of businesses? The question wells up in me every time I see another Facebook scandal grabbing headlines, or hear the latest on the Dominoâs accessibility lawsuit. I wonder about it every time the question or Uber or Airbnbâs impact on communities pops back up in the Twittersphere.
The thing is: itâs a false question. Design has always and already been at every table in âThe Business.â
They just donât call themselves designers. Or, in some cases, value the things weâve come to expect designers to value. They arenât necessarily fighting for users, or even trying to balance user goals and experience with business value. In many cases, the business value â i.e., shareholder gains â is whatâs truly paramount in their minds.
Now, this isnât meant as an excoriation of these folks. Without wading into the morass of ethics, I get why theyâre focused on shareholder value, and why evocations of âfreedom of speechâ tend to crop up in their arguments (misplaced as they are).
Itâs merely intended as a corrective. âDesignâ as such doesnât need a previously unassigned seat at the table. What weâre often arguing for is instead a different view of design. A principled and conscious approach to the design of systems (i.e., businesses) that takes into account the myriad other systems each business impacts, from the political landscape to the local housing market.
So, to return to Amyâs point above: the thing to focus on while youâre fighting for your seat at the table is the development of your strategy for making use of that seat. And to my mind, a key starting point for the development of that strategy is the acknowledgement that design is very much happening at that seat. Itâs up to you to, in the words of Mad Menâs Don Draper, change the conversation about design thatâs already happening there.
Because, like it or not, everyone truly is a designer. (Yep!) But more on that in the next section.
Or course, as Maxim Leyzerovich notes here:
Designâs gaining of a seat at the table isnât purely a one-sided affair. Both brands that want to give design a seat at the table and the designers who want to give it one need to be thinking about how design will thrive within an organization if it wants to attract and keep talent.
And, in confirmation of designâs potential to positively influence âfrom the table,â each of these things arenât design-specific â theyâre necessities for any modern org, which will shape perception of a brand for any professional, but also for the broader public.
So, if youâve been fighting for a seat at the table, itâs past time to be asking yourself: What are you going to do with that seat?
Speaking with the voice of experience here: org design is an incredible â and fun â challenge. Working in the media of identities and careers is far more dynamic than pixels.
8. Role is not identity Is everyone a designer? Yes, just as everyone is a writer.
(Trust me: Iâm a professional writer. And the more I try to deny others that role, the higher my stress levels and the harder my work gets. The more I include other writersâ perspectives, regardless of their individual skill levels, the better my work tends to get. Though it sure does make line edits more complicated.)
The difference between you, titled designer, and any other person who designs without the title, is not one of kind, but of degree. Writing and design are skills, not identities, so âbeingâ a writer or designer is more like occupying a spot on a spectrum. (A lot like gender, ya know?).
The difference is in skill level, primarily, but also in education and context. Just because we all design doesnât mean weâre all good at it.
The important thing to realize, however, is that your role is not your identity. Not who you are. The claim that a writer, lawyer, or product manager designs shouldnât feel like a threat to your identity not only because itâs simply a skill, but because itâs not your identity.
The problem with overidentifying with a skill â with considering it a part of your identity â is that your identity can then be threatened by all sorts of small attacks. Whenever your work is criticized, you become the subject of that criticism. Whenever a ânon-designerâ (or non-whatever) applies their skill better than you did, you were outdone not in skill, but in identity. Makes you wonder if this sort of overidentification has a part to play in our industryâs ongoing struggle with impostor syndrome â¦
But actor Sam Neill says all this much better than I. So, over to you, Sam:
9. Okay, one visual trend: marquee is back, baby!â
And I know weâre all excited by excited by excited by that.
A vision for web design we can all (hopefully) get behind When I read back over this post, I for one canât help but feel a stirring of hope. Because these 9 trends all suggest a future for website design that I canât help but love.
A web design devoted to helping people understand whatâs true and what isnât. A web design for all, regardless of ability, or identity. A web design thatâs inclusive of creators who do things a little differently â that is, code visually.
None of this is going to be easy. There will be pushback. There will be those who donât want to sacrifice numbers for the sake of making principled stands.

- PÃ©rou: l'ex-prÃ©sident Vizcarra mis en cause pour un vaccin (Un soignant vaccine Ã une femme indigÃ¨ne contre le Covid-19, le 13 fÃ©vrier 2021 prÃ¨s de Santarem, au BrÃ©sil ( AFP / Tarso SARRAF )) Un soignant vaccine Ã une femme indigÃ¨ne contre le Covid-19, le 13 fÃ©vrier 2021 prÃ¨s de Santarem, au BrÃ©sil ( AFP / Tarso SARRAF )
Le mÃ©decin qui a dirigÃ© en 2020 au PÃ©rou l'essai clinique du vaccin chinois Sinopharm a affirmÃ© mardi devant le Parlement que l'ex-prÃ©sident Martin Vizcarra, mis en cause dans un scandale liÃ© Ã la vaccination contre le Covid-19, avait Ã©tÃ© immunisÃ© en octobre en dehors de l'essai et Ã sa demande.Â
Lundi, le prÃ©sident Francisco Sagasti a rÃ©vÃ©lÃ© que 487 personnes avaient Ã©tÃ© vaccinÃ©es indÃ»ment contre le Covid-19, dont, outre deux ministres dÃ©missionnaires, d'autres fonctionnaires, qui seront dÃ©mis de leurs fonctions.
- La CorÃ©e du Nord en mal de vaccins - (Un tunnel en plastique pour isoler les patients atteints du Covid-19, le 16 fÃ©vrier 2021 Ã Bogota, en Colombie ( AFP / Juan BARRETO )) Un tunnel en plastique pour isoler les patients atteints du Covid-19, le 16 fÃ©vrier 2021 Ã Bogota, en Colombie ( AFP / Juan BARRETO )
Des hackers nord-corÃ©ens ont cherchÃ© Ã pÃ©nÃ©trer les systÃ¨mes informatiques du gÃ©ant pharmaceutique Pfizer pour trouver des informations sur le vaccin et les traitements contre le coronavirus, rapportent mardi des mÃ©dias citant les services de renseignement sud-corÃ©ens.
- Biden dÃ©fend son plan de sauvetage - "Il faut dÃ©penser maintenant, il faut frapper fort", a lancÃ© le prÃ©sident amÃ©ricain Joe Biden en vantant les mÃ©rites de son gigantesque plan de sauvetage de l'Ã©conomie de 1.900 milliards de dollars.
- Les nouveaux cas de Covid ont chutÃ© de 16% selon l'OMS - Le nombre de nouveaux cas de Covid-19 signalÃ©s dans le monde a chutÃ© de 16% la semaine derniÃ¨re, pour atteindre 2,7 millions, a annoncÃ© mardi soir l'Organisation mondiale de la santÃ© (OMS).Â
(Nombre de morts liÃ©s au coronavirus officiellement annoncÃ©s par pays, au 16 fÃ©vrier Ã 11H00 GMT ( AFP / )) Nombre de morts liÃ©s au coronavirus officiellement annoncÃ©s par pays, au 16 fÃ©vrier Ã 11H00 GMT ( AFP / )
Le nombre de nouveaux dÃ©cÃ¨s signalÃ©s a Ã©galement diminuÃ© de 10% par rapport Ã la semaine prÃ©cÃ©dente, atteignant 81.000, selon la mise Ã jour Ã©pidÃ©miologique hebdomadaire de l'OMS, basÃ©e sur les donnÃ©es jusqu'Ã dimanche.Â
La pandÃ©mie du nouveau coronavirus a fait au moins 2.408.243 morts dans le monde depuis fin dÃ©cembre 2019, selon un bilan Ã©tabli par l'AFP Ã partir de sources officielles mardi.
AprÃ¨s les Etats-Unis (487.714 morts), les pays comptant le plus de dÃ©cÃ¨s sont le BrÃ©sil (240.940), le Mexique (175.986), l'Inde (155.813) et le Royaume-Uni (117.396).
Le Mexique a franchi mardi la barre des deux millions de cas de Covid-19 depuis le dÃ©but de la pandÃ©mie.
Le nombre des victimes est globalement sous-Ã©valuÃ©. Il se fonde sur les bilans quotidiens des autoritÃ©s nationales de santÃ© mais exclut les rÃ©visions rÃ©alisÃ©es Ã posteriori par des organismes statistiques.

ami:document.ami:content:
"Nous nous fÃ©licitons des dÃ©cisions des rÃ©gulateurs qui affirment le bÃ©nÃ©fice de notre vaccin pour arrÃªter la pandÃ©mie", a dÃ©clarÃ© dans un communiquÃ© Ann Taylor, mÃ©decin chef d'AstraZenaca, soulignant sa confiance que les vaccinations puissent reprendre en Europe.Â
Une quinzaine de pays, dont l'Allemagne, la France et l'Italie, avaient suspendu par prÃ©caution l'utilisation de ce vaccin aprÃ¨s le signalement d'effets secondaires tels que des troubles de la coagulation et la formation de caillots.Â
ReconfinÃ©e aux trois quarts depuis lundi, l'Italie reprendra dÃ¨s vendredi les vaccinations avec l'AstraZeneca, tout comme la France, l'Allemagne, la Bulgarie ou encore la SlovÃ©nie. D'autres pays s'y remettront la semaine prochaine, tels l'Espagne, le Portugal ou les Pays-Bas.Â
La NorvÃ¨ge et la SuÃ¨de, par contre, vont attendre d'avoir effectuÃ© la semaine prochaine leurs propres Ã©valuations, car une Ã©quipe mÃ©dicale norvÃ©gienne dit voir un lien entre le produit et des caillots sanguins observÃ©s chez des patients tombÃ©s dans un Ã©tat grave, voire dÃ©cÃ©dÃ©s, quelques jours aprÃ¨s une premiÃ¨re injection.Â
L'Organisation mondiale de la santÃ© (OMS) a renouvelÃ© jeudi son appel Ã continuer Ã utiliser ce vaccin. Son ComitÃ© consultatif mondial de la sÃ©curitÃ© vaccinale (GACVS) doit publier vendredi un avis Ã son propos.Â
Peu avant l'EMA, le rÃ©gulateur sanitaire britannique, le MHRA, qui examinait les vaccins AstraZeneca et Pfizer/BioNTech, avait Ã©galement conclu "qu'il n'y a aucune preuve que les caillots sanguins dans les veines se produisent plus que ce Ã quoi on pourrait s'attendre en l'absence de vaccination, pour l'un comme l'autre vaccin".Â
Le Royaume-Uni a annoncÃ© une rÃ©duction de ses approvisionnements en vaccins en avril, susceptible de ralentir sa campagne de vaccination, l'une des plus avancÃ©es au monde.Â
Selon les mÃ©dias britanniques, le problÃ¨me d'approvisionnement est dÃ» Ã un retard de livraison de cinq millions de doses produites en Inde par le Serum Institute pour AstraZeneca.Â
La Commission europÃ©enne a de son cÃ´tÃ© annoncÃ© qu'elle allait activer une procÃ©dure contractuelle pour rÃ©soudre le conflit avec AstraZeneca, dont les livraisons sont nettement infÃ©rieures aux chiffres prÃ©vus.Â
- "Taper trÃ¨s dur" -Â
MalgrÃ© ces dÃ©convenues, la vaccination a continuÃ© d'accÃ©lÃ©rer. Au moins 402,3 millions de doses ont Ã©tÃ© administrÃ©es dans le monde, dont plus d'un quart aux Etats-Unis, selon un comptage de l'AFP arrÃªtÃ© jeudi Ã 16H30 GMT.Â
La situation Ã©pidÃ©mique reste nÃ©anmoins "particuliÃ¨rement" inquiÃ©tante dans les Balkans et en Europe centrale, selon l'OMS, Ã l'heure oÃ¹ le nombre de cas en Europe augmente pour la troisiÃ¨me semaine consÃ©cutive.Â
"Le nombre de personnes qui meurent du Covid-19 en Europe est plus Ã©levÃ© aujourd'hui qu'il ne l'Ã©tait Ã la mÃªme Ã©poque l'annÃ©e derniÃ¨re", a soulignÃ© le directeur Europe de l'OMS, Hans Kluge.Â
La pandÃ©mie a fait au moins 2,68 millions de morts dans le monde, selon un bilan Ã©tabli jeudi par l'AFP, et nombre de pays sont engagÃ©s dans une course contre la montre avec le virus.Â
C'est le cas de la France, oÃ¹ s'approche la barre des 100.000 morts: le gouvernement, Ã©voquant une "troisiÃ¨me vague", a annoncÃ© dans la soirÃ©e un troisiÃ¨me confinement en un an, plus souple que les prÃ©cÃ©dents.Â
Plus de 20 millions de FranÃ§ais, dont les habitants de la rÃ©gion parisienne, vont de nouveau Ãªtre confinÃ©s Ã partir de vendredi et pour un mois. Les Ã©coles et commerces essentiels (dont les librairies) resteront ouverts.Â
L'Ã©pidÃ©mie accÃ©lÃ¨re nettement dans le pays, oÃ¹ plus de 38.000 contaminations ont Ã©tÃ© enregistrÃ©es en 24 heures. "La situation est clairement critique. Ãa va taper trÃ¨s dur jusqu'Ã la mi-avril", avait soulignÃ© mercredi soir le prÃ©sident Emmanuel Macron.Â
- Hommage en Italie -Â
L'Italie commÃ©morait quant Ã elle jeudi les plus de 103.000 morts de l'Ã©pidÃ©mie de Covid-19, avec drapeaux en berne sur les bÃ¢timents publics.Â
Le Premier ministre est venu se recueillir Ã Bergame (nord), ville du nord du pays restÃ©e associÃ©e aux images de camions militaires transportant des cercueils en pleine nuit il y a un an.Â
En Allemagne, Ã©galement touchÃ©e par une troisiÃ¨me vague, le gouvernement a appelÃ© la population Ã Ãªtre "responsable" et Ã ne pas se rendre dans la trÃ¨s prisÃ©e Ã®le espagnole de Majorque, malgrÃ© l'affrÃ¨tement de centaines de vols touristiques.Â
Plusieurs responsables rÃ©gionaux allemands ont exhortÃ© jeudi les autoritÃ©s europÃ©ennes Ã accÃ©lÃ©rer l'examen du vaccin russe Spoutnik V et Ã anticiper son dÃ©ploiement dans l'UE.Â
La Bulgarie, qui se targuait jusqu'Ã prÃ©sent de mesures souples face Ã la pandÃ©mie, a annoncÃ© jeudi un durcissement de ses restrictions, alors que le nombre de contaminations y augmente fortement. Ecoles, universitÃ©s, restaurants, thÃ©Ã¢tres, cinÃ©mas, centres commerciaux, casinos et salles de sport y fermeront Ã partir de lundi pour dix jours.Â
En Ukraine, le maire de Kiev, Vitali Klitchko, a annoncÃ© le renforcement des restrictions dans la capitale Ã partir de samedi pour trois semaines.Â
Au Chili, un reconfinement strict du tiers du pays entre en vigueur jeudi, malgrÃ© la progression rapide de la campagne de vaccination dans ce pays.Â

ami:document.ami:content:
"GrÃ¢ce Ã toutes les personnes qui ont combattu sans relÃ¢che pour que le droit Ã mourir dignement soit reconnu en Espagne", cette loi "devient enfin une rÃ©alitÃ©", a-t-il ajoutÃ©.Â
L'Espagne devient ainsi le quatriÃ¨me pays europÃ©en Ã dÃ©pÃ©naliser l'euthanasie, aprÃ¨s les Pays-Bas, la Belgique et le Luxembourg. Â
Le parlement portugais a Ã©galement votÃ© fin janvier une loi lÃ©galisant l'euthanasie, mais la Cour constitutionnelle a retoquÃ© lundi le texte, qui va Ãªtre renvoyÃ© aux dÃ©putÃ©s.Â
La loi espagnole autorise aussi bien l'euthanasie - c'est Ã dire lorsque le soignant provoque la mort du patient - que le suicide mÃ©dicalement assistÃ© - lorsque le patient prend lui-mÃªme la dose de produit prescrite pour se donner la mort.Â
- Strictes conditions -Â
Elle prÃ©voit que toute personne ayant "une maladie grave et incurable" ou des douleurs "chroniques le plaÃ§ant dans une situation d'incapacitÃ©" puisse demander l'aide du corps mÃ©dical pour mourir et s'Ã©viter ainsi "une souffrance intolÃ©rable".Â
Des conditions strictes encadrent toutefois la dÃ©marche: la personne, espagnole ou rÃ©sidant dans le pays, doit ainsi Ãªtre "capable et consciente" lorsqu'elle fait la demande, qui doit Ãªtre formulÃ©e par Ã©crit "sans pression extÃ©rieure" et renouvelÃ©e quinze jours plus tard.Â
Le mÃ©decin pourra toujours rejeter cette demande s'il estime que ces critÃ¨res ne sont pas remplis ou faire valoir "son objection de conscience". En outre, elle devra Ãªtre approuvÃ©e par un autre mÃ©decin et recevoir le feu vert d'une commission d'Ã©valuation.Â
L'adoption de cette loi intervient aprÃ¨s plusieurs cas emblÃ©matiques dans le pays au cours des derniÃ¨res dÃ©cennies, dont celui de RamÃ³n Sampedro, un homme tÃ©traplÃ©gique incarnÃ© Ã l'Ã©cran par Javier Bardem dans le film oscarisÃ© "Mar adentro".Â
C'est une victoire "pour les gens qui pourront en bÃ©nÃ©ficier", et aussi "pour RamÃ³n", s'est fÃ©licitÃ© auprÃ¨s de l'AFP Ramona Maneiro, l'amie de M. Sampedro qui l'a aidÃ© Ã mourir en 1998. Â
- "Homicide" -Â
Vent debout contre cette rÃ©forme, l'Eglise catholique espagnole a comparÃ© l'euthanasie Ã "une forme d'homicide" tandis que le parti d'extrÃªme droite Vox a annoncÃ© qu'il dÃ©poserait un recours devant le Tribunal constitutionnel.Â
DÃ©guisÃ©s en faucheuses noires pour certains et dÃ©ployant une banderole contre le "gouvernement de la mort", au son de tambours funÃ¨bres, une centaine d'opposants Ã la loi ont manifestÃ© jeudi devant les portes de la Chambre des dÃ©putÃ©s.Â
Cette loi "viole le droit Ã la vie, sans lequel aucun autre n'existe", a dÃ©noncÃ© l'un de ces militants, Alexander Cuevas, 21 ans.Â
Polonia Castellanos, porte-parole de l'Association espagnole des avocats chrÃ©tiens, a, elle, dÃ©plorÃ© un "jour triste (...) ne laissant aucune libertÃ© Ã ceux qui souffrent et que l'on pousse Ã choisir la solution la plus rapide: la mort".Â
Une dizaine de militants pro-euthanasie se sont rÃ©unis au mÃªme endroit peu de temps avant, comme Asun Gomez Bueno, dont le mari atteint de sclÃ©rose en plaque est mort Ã 50 ans aprÃ¨s des annÃ©es de souffrance. Â
Saluant un "jour trÃ¨s heureux", elle a regrettÃ© qu'on l'ait "traitÃ©e d'assassine" car elle avait voulu "aider (son) mari Ã arrÃªter de souffrir".Â
Depuis que l'euthanasie a surgi dans le dÃ©bat public, plusieurs cas retentissants ont dÃ©frayÃ© la chronique en Espagne. L'un des plus rÃ©cents est celui d'Ãngel HernÃ¡ndez, arrÃªtÃ© en 2019 pour avoir aidÃ© sa femme atteinte de sclÃ©rose en plaques Ã mourir, et qui attend d'Ãªtre jugÃ©.Â
