ami:document.ami:content:
At Vimeo, I am the sole UX writer/content strategist for all of our products, across all platforms. Whether weâre testing new player outros, optimizing Vimeo On Demand title pages, or launching a new suite of creator tools geared toward businesses, I am the human behind all the words embedded in the UI. Because I write for so many different products and platforms, Iâm always hopping across a bunch of different teams at once â and each team has its own special way of getting things done.
This array of working styles, tools, and processes quickly becomes a nightmare for a type-A organization freak like myself â especially when it comes to keeping track of the copy Iâve written, and making sure itâs consistent.
Fast & furious Our creator tools team likes to work quick and dirty, in two-week sprints. Often, Iâm brought in at the beginning of the sprint to learn about what weâre trying to launch and why. Iâm involved in early feature conception and user testing, and I work alongside the designer to review mocks and provide copy that works within them. In theory, we have a final design review together so that I can QA all copy and make sure we havenât missed any error states, etc. In reality? Iâm often stalking Zeplin projects to make sure Iâve seen the most up-to-date designs before dev gets too far along with their build. But when I find something that needs to be changed, what to do? Do I comment in Zeplin and tag the designer? Or do I ticket the issue in GitHub and assign it to the lead dev to update in the build only? Or do I pass it to the QA specialist first?
Along with being unsure about the best way to get copy updated before a feature goes into production, I also wonder if I should even bother being diligent in updating my original copy deck. When the developers are referencing the designs for copy anyhow, does it matter? The answer is pretty much always yes. And in fact, our developers really like having one place where they can find *all* of the copy related to a given project, including error states and upsell messages that may not be laid out in the comps.
One source of truthThe need for âone copy repository to rule them allâ comes up a lot, especially when Iâm working on mobile projects. I try to reuse copy across platforms to ensure brand consistency throughout our many mobile and TV apps. When a designer comes to me asking about Apple TV empty states, I like to be able to reference the versions I wrote for iOS a few months back. For a long time, that process consisted of me digging back through my archive of original copy decks.
If something changed between when I initially wrote the deck â letâs say we made a last-minute update before pushing something out to mods (staff members with special permissions) â and I didnât record that update, Iâd be repurposing incorrect copy. And given that Iâm spread so thin across projects, I may not realize this right away. Not cool.
I wanted one place, one doc, to house all of the strings I was writing for iOS, Android, Apple TV, Roku, etc.
A janky string CMSI wanted to be able to âtagâ each string with the platform I wrote it for so Iâd know whatâs what without having to reproduce obscure error states within the app at a later date. I also wanted to sort strings by the section of the app in which they appear, and the action or feature they relate to. And I didnât want to have to wade through code in Github to do so. Most importantly of all, perhaps, is that I wanted to empower our engineers to hop into this doc and find pre-approved copy to get a head start on their build. (Of course, I still want to QA any copy theyâre implementing to make sure theyâre using the right line in the right place, and that theyâre adhering to our style guidelines.) OK, but actually most importantly is that I wanted to create a system that would scale as we add more writers to our team (a girl can dream).
Iâm still waiting for the perfect solution, but for now, Iâve got a very budget CMS of sorts: I created a Google Spreadsheet with different tabs/sheets for different types of strings. For instance, I have tabs for:
- README - Alerts/Confirmations - Context - Empty States - Error Messages - Labels/Menus - Logged-Out States - Player - Screens - Success Messages
This way, if a mobile designer asks me to help write copy for a setting of upload error messages, which I know Iâve touched before, I can go into the âError Messagesâ tab, and sort the âSectionâ column from Z-A to pull all of the âUploadâ strings up to the top. Then, I can quickly scan the âDescriptionâ column to find the error messages. Or, I can just ctr+F to find any error messages that reference âupload.â As I mentioned, this a fairly janky approach, but Iâve yet to find a better way to record and search for the strings Iâve written.
A plea for helpAll this said, I know there must be a better way that Iâm not aware of yet. Iâm writing this post in hopes that someone who is more crafty than I will propose a more efficient and flexible solution for managing heaps of product copy â ideally one that already exists. If you are that magical person, please shoot me a comment!
ami:document.ami:description: - README - Alerts/Confirmations - Context - Empty States - Error Messages - Labels/Menus - Logged-Out States - Player - Screens - Success Messages. This way, if a mobile designer asks me to help write copy for a setting of upload error messages, which I know Iâve touched before, I can go into the âError Messagesâ tab, and sort the âSectionâ column from Z-A to pull all of the âUploadâ strings up to the top.

C'est la signature de cette charte le 15 mars par les opÃ©rateurs (Bouygues Telecom, Free Mobile, Orange et SFR) qui a rendu possible le lancement commercial de la 5G Ã Paris, alors que les villes franciliennes de la petite couronne bÃ©nÃ©ficient de la couverture de la derniÃ¨re gÃ©nÃ©ration de rÃ©seau mobile depuis fin 2020.Â

Les opÃ©rateurs et les pouvoirs publics ont cherchÃ© toutefois Ã trouver un compromis politique pour dÃ©samorcer un sujet devenu encore plus polÃ©mique depuis que la Convention citoyenne pour le climat a elle-mÃªme recommandÃ© un moratoire cet Ã©tÃ©.Â

Une opÃ©ration policiÃ¨re avait Ã©tÃ© lancÃ©e Ã 06H30 (05H30 GMT) pour l'extraire de l'universitÃ© de LÃ©rida, en Catalogne (nord-est de l'Espagne), oÃ¹ il Ã©tait barricadÃ© depuis lundi avec des dizaines de sympathisants qui voulaient empÃªcher son arrestation.Â
Pablo HasÃ©l -- de son vrai nom Pablo Rivadulla DurÃ³ -- avait jusqu'Ã vendredi soir pour se rendre volontairement en prison et commencer Ã y purger la peine de neuf mois qui lui avait Ã©tÃ© infligÃ©e par la justice espagnole.Â
Reconnu coupable d'apologie du terrorisme, ainsi que d'injures et calomnies Ã l'encontre de la couronne et de l'Etat, il avait Ã©tÃ© condamnÃ© pour des tweets dans lesquels il qualifiait notamment les forces de l'ordre espagnoles de "mercenaires de merde", les accusait de torture et d'assassinats et s'en prenait Ã©galement Ã la monarchie.Â
"Ils devront venir m'enlever et cela servira aussi Ã dÃ©peindre l'Ãtat sous son vrai visage, celui d'une fausse dÃ©mocratie", avait dÃ©clarÃ© Ã l'AFP ce rappeur catalan de 32 ans vendredi par tÃ©lÃ©phone.Â
- "EpÃ©e de DamoclÃ¨s" -Â
Plusieurs manifestations parfois tendues en soutien Ã Pablo HasÃ©l avaient eu lieu ces derniÃ¨res semaines Ã Madrid et Barcelone, tandis que plus de 200 personnalitÃ©s du monde culturel hispanophone, dont le rÃ©alisateur Pedro AlmodÃ³var et l'acteur Javier Bardem, avaient signÃ© une tribune en sa faveur.Â
Les signataires y affirmaient notamment que la condamnation de Pablo HasÃ©l constituait une "Ã©pÃ©e de DamoclÃ¨s" au-dessus de tous les artistes et accusaient l'Espagne d'agir comme "la Turquie ou le Maroc". Â
L'affaire Ã©tait devenue une vÃ©ritable Ã©pine dans le pied du gouvernement de gauche de Pedro Sanchez, Ã plus forte raison Ã l'approche des Ã©lections catalanes de dimanche dernier.Â
La porte-parole de l'exÃ©cutif, MarÃ­a JesÃºs Montero, avait ainsi reconnu la semaine derniÃ¨re "un manque de proportionnalitÃ©" dans la peine infligÃ©e au rappeur. Â
Sur la dÃ©fensive, le gouvernement avait Ã©galement promis "une rÃ©forme" pour que les "excÃ¨s verbaux commis dans le cadre de manifestations artistiques, culturelles ou intellectuelles" ne relÃ¨vent plus du droit pÃ©nal et ne se traduisent plus par des peines de prison.Â
Partenaire des socialistes au sein du gouvernement, le parti de gauche radicale Podemos a vertement dÃ©noncÃ© mardi l'arrestation du rappeur.Â
"Tous ceux qui se considÃ¨rent progressistes et se vantent de la +pleine normalitÃ© dÃ©mocratique+ (de l'Espagne), devraient avoir honte. Vont-ils fermer les yeux ? Il n'y a pas de progrÃ¨s si nous ne voulons pas reconnaÃ®tre les manques dÃ©mocratiques actuels", a twittÃ© Podemos.Â
Il s'agissait d'une allusion Ã des commentaires rÃ©cents trÃ¨s controversÃ©s de son chef, Pablo Iglesias, qui avait dÃ©clarÃ© la semaine derniÃ¨re qu'il n'y avait pas "une situation de pleine normalitÃ© politique et dÃ©mocratique en Espagne".Â
Ces propos avaient dÃ©clenchÃ© un tollÃ© de la part de la part de tous les partis de l'opposition de droite, mais aussi un Ã©norme malaise au sein mÃªme du Parti socialiste de Pedro SÃ¡nchez.Â
Le cas de Pablo HasÃ©l rappelle celui d'un autre rappeur espagnol, Valtonyc. Ce dernier s'Ã©tait exilÃ© en Belgique en mai 2018 aprÃ¨s confirmation de sa condamnation en Espagne Ã trois ans et demi de prison pour "apologie du terrorisme" et du groupe sÃ©paratiste basque ETA, "injures Ã la Couronne" et "menaces" dans ses chansons.Â
Il est visÃ© depuis par un mandat d'arrÃªt europÃ©en Ã©mis par la justice espagnole. En septembre 2018, un tribunal de Gand avait rejetÃ© l'exÃ©cution du mandat. La procÃ©dure est toujours en cours devant une cour d'appel.Â

ami:document.ami:content:
(A few sketchbooks rest beside a vase filled with flowers.) (A few sketchbooks rest beside a vase filled with flowers.) (A few sketchbooks rest beside a vase filled with flowers.) The misconception that UI/UX design is an art form harms designers. Photo by Joanna Kosinska on Unsplash . I used to date a professional painter. Like âpay rent and keep the lights on with commissionsâ professional painter. Not just an artist, but an Arteest. Now, I know what youâre thinking: âCodeyâs dated someone before? Doubtful.â And trust me, Iâm every bit as surprised by my dating luck as you are. But weâre getting sidetracked.
Iâd see Emma (name changed for privacy reasons) spend months on a single commission. Sheâd take a few weeks to brainstorm and search for inspiration. After Emma finally decided what to paint, sheâd spend hours prepping the canvas. Sheâd lose sleep with countless late nights as she pored over every detail. I once watched her spend a whole day perfecting the pigmentation on a single shadow.
On one occasion, after putting all that time and effort into a commission, a client said âHmm. Iâm not sure I like it. Can you do something else?â Rightfully crestfallen, Emma recommenced the entire process.
When I first started designing UI and UX, I often found myself in similar situations: spending countless hours on a project only to hear that my design âjust doesnât look right.â It wasnât until I saw one of Emmaâs clients say those same words that I realized my problem: I treated my designs as though they were art commissions.
Treating UI/UX design as though itâs art is bad practice. When we treat UI/UX design as though itâs art, we do ourselves a disservice for a few reasons. First, treating design like art propagates the fallacious notion that good design is subjective. As Iâll discuss later, good design is objective; it possesses measurable criteria that we can use to assess its value.
Next, treating design as though itâs art spreads the false notion that design is an innate skill that canât be taught. You donât need Picasso-level intrinsic artistic talent to master digital product design. Good design can absolutely be taught and teaching good design comprises a large part of my goal for this article.
Finally, treating design as though itâs art severely limits what you can do with your designs. As Iâll discuss later, good design empathizes with its user and creatively solves its usersâ problems. When we treat design as art, we tend to prioritize aesthetics and visuals over usability and problem solving, which will deliver a severely limited product 11 times out of 10.
Good UI/UX design is science. Ultimately, good digital product design is a science. It solves problems, begins with empathy, adheres to the scientific method, is objective, and can be taught. With this article, I intend to prove that good design is a science that can be mastered, and provide actionable steps along the way for achieving good design.
Alright, this intro has already dragged on for wayyy too long. So without further ado, here are 5 reasons why good UI/UX design is science, not art.
1. Good Design solves problems. Art doesnât (at least not inherently). Just like science, UI/UX design seeks to identify â and ultimately solve â problems. The very first step of the scientific method is to identify a problem (more on this later). Your designs should not exist solely for their aesthetic value. They should get sh*t done. Art, on the other hand, does not inherently solve problems. I know that sometimes art advocates for certain causes, probes us to think deeply about societal injustice, and asks us to question internal biases. Good art can identify problems. But it doesnât usually offer its audience actionable steps to solve the problems it identifies. For both science and design, on the other hand, solving problems is the whole point.
(A woman views sculptures in an art gallery.) (A woman views sculptures in an art gallery.) (A woman views sculptures in an art gallery.) Art is necessary and important, but does not necessarily exist for the sole purpose of solving its consumersâ problems. Photo by Azka Firas on Unsplash .Danielle Miller, a designer for the award-winning team over at Clockwork writes, âSmart user experience design starts by identifying a problem and guiding all ideas to solve that problem.â This âproblemâ could refer to a variety of different needs a user might have. A well-designed e-commerce site, for example, might solve a userâs problem by helping the customer make an informed purchase, with confidence that theyâve ordered the right product. A well designed ride-share app can solve a userâs problem by getting them home safely after a night out with friends.
Successful products solve problems. That problem might be getting a user from unregistered to registered for an event. It might mean communicating a brandâs vision so customers can understand it. Whether weâre talking about an app, a website, or more nuanced digital experience, UX design stands guard against offering features for the sake of offering features. â Danielle Miller, Clockwork
Still not on board? Letâs take a look at some examples. Weâll start with an extreme example of a website that looks beautiful, but is ultimately useless because it doesnât solve any problems.
(A screenshot of corndog.io.) (A screenshot of corndog.io.) (A screenshot of corndog.io.) Corndog.io is a beautiful website but a bad UI/UX design because it doesnât solve any problems.Look at corndog.io . Now that is a beautiful website. Very few things in life compare to the beauty of a fresh, crispy corndog. But does it make the cut for good digital product design? It absolutely does not. Because it doesnât solve any problems; itâs just corn dogs floating across your screen. Letâs shift our focus to a more realistic example.
Before I dissect the following piece of UI, I should note that Outcrowd, the agency responsible for creating it, is utterly fantastic. On the whole, theyâre incredibly talented and I can only dream of publishing work even remotely close to the quality products that they churn out on a daily basis. But hereâs an example of when they let their artwork overshadow their UX.
(A UI design whose art overshadows its UX.) (A UI design whose art overshadows its UX.) (A UI design whose art overshadows its UX.) This landing page is art, and itâs beautiful, but itâs not good design.Hereâs a landing page for Paulini, a fictional travel library for tourists. This design is beautiful. The illustration is tasteful. I canât overstate how good this looks. But whether a design looks good bears little weight on whether the design is usable. When I look at this landing page, itâs not immediately clear what problems this site solves for a user. I can spot a few links resting cozily in the top nav. I notice a call-to-action. I see some very vague directions in the bottom left corner of the page. But itâs anyoneâs guess as to where each nav-link leads, or what Iâd be âdiscovering moreâ of if I click on the call-to-action. This landing page is art. Itâs beautiful. But it doesnât solve any problems.
So letâs take a look at a design that does solve problems. Now that weâve considered a couple nonexamples, we should consider a UI that gets it right. And weâll give Outcrowd a shot at redemption while weâre at it.
(A UI design that is both artful and has great UX.) (A UI design that is both artful and has great UX.) (A UI design that is both artful and has great UX.) This landing page is both beautiful and functional.Above you can see a landing page designed by the same agency, for a similar product: Wedly constitutes another fictional travel agency. This design is equally beautiful. The illustration is equally tasteful. The difference lies in this landing pageâs usability. This design not only solves problems, but it communicates clearly which problems it solves. The problem? A traveler wants an unforgettable experience â a step above the average tourist trip. This is a website solves that problem by helping travelers plan that experience. Itâs clear where each nav link leads. Itâs clear what happens when I click the call-to-action. This is top-notch design.
I promised in the introduction that I wouldnât just point out examples of good and bad design. I told you Iâd also offer actionable steps for achieving good design. So how does a designer make sure theyâre crafting UI and UX that solves problems? Danielle Miller, whom I mentioned earlier, offers three ways we can master this technique.
First, we need to conduct research. Before we even begin sketching out our ideas for a product or service, we need to âunderstand how that product or service fits into the userâs life.â If you encounter difficulties during your user research, Fabricio Teixeira wrote an excellent article about what kinds of questions to ask â and how to ask them â during user research.
Second, Miller says that we should constantly be asking âwhy.â Every button, every paragraph, every element, ask âWhy is this important? Why am I adding this?â
Finally, any time you design an element within a UI, ask yourself âwhat problem does this solve?â If you donât have an answer, that element is probably superfluous.
2. Good UI/UX design begins with empathy. Art doesnât necessarily (although it really should). If both science and design solve problems, then empathy is a prerequisite to both industries. How can you effectively solve a problem for someone if you donât know that personâs priorities, cognitive and physical restrictions, and other needs? When science fails to begin with empathy, it creates the wrong solution to the wrong problem for the wrong stakeholders. The same is true for UI/UX design.
Let me offer the way my home city of Boston handled the pandemic as an example. When COVID-19 struck Boston, many of our cityâs officials and social scientists realized that we have a rather large population of essential workers. Iâm talking medical professionals, public transit workers, grocery store staff. We had a huge number of people who simply couldnât work from home due to the nature of their job, and many of those folks simply cannot afford frequent testing at private healthcare providers. These essential workers also come into contact with hundreds of people each day, highlighting the necessity for the workers to be completely healthy when they clock in, so they donât spread the virus while at work. Thus the cityâs officials and social scientists recognized our problem of needing multiple free testing centers.
(People wait in line to receive a free Covid-19 test in Boston, MA.) (People wait in line to receive a free Covid-19 test in Boston, MA.) (People wait in line to receive a free Covid-19 test in Boston, MA.) Photo by Jakayla Toney on Unsplash .Unfortunately, those faced with the task of solving this problem did not begin with empathy. The majority of our initial free testing sites were not accessible via public transit. For one reason or another, the majority of people in Boston with jobs deemed âessentialâ donât own their own vehicle. So we had a solution to the problem (free testing sites), but the solution clearly failed to consider the physical restrictions of the people whose problem we wanted to solve. Had our cityâs problem solvers begun with empathy, we couldâve avoided this mess. Thankfully, Bostonâs officials quickly realized their mistake and worked to correct it. However, this example proves the need for any scientific process to begin with empathy. Good digital product design also begins with empathy. Fortunately for us designers, however, we have a lot less at stake than the transmission of a deadly virus. Letâs take a look at some examples.
When I first began my design career, I didnât have many design projects under my belt, so I populated my portfolio with some sample projects and redesigns of existing products that I had made in my spare time. For one of these sample projects, I reimagined Wikipedia, specifically the article on our galaxy, the Milky Way.
(A redesign of Wikipedia that I made when I was first starting out as a designer.) (A redesign of Wikipedia that I made when I was first starting out as a designer.) (A redesign of Wikipedia that I made when I was first starting out as a designer.) A design can be beautiful and artistic, but if it doesnât begin with empathy, it wonât solve any problems.This design is pretty (in my humble opinion). Itâs clean and organized. Thereâs plenty of room for the content to breathe. On the surface, my Wikipedia redesign might look like some good UI. But it is, in fact, utterly useless crap.
My Wikipedia redesign is crap because it didnât begin with empathy. Wikipedia aims to deliver reliable information to even the most remote, information-starved locations with limited internet access. Wikipediaâs strength lies in its light weight and versatility. Democratizing information means that even the slowest internet connection should be able to access that information. My redesign would require a hefty style sheet. A massive header image and a dynamic table of contents widget would take a while to load, seriously limiting which users can access the site, effectively defeating Wikipediaâs entire purpose. I failed to account for my intended usersâ physical limitations.
(A screenshot of Wikipediaâs main page.) (A screenshot of Wikipediaâs main page.) (A screenshot of Wikipediaâs main page.) Wikipediaâs strength lies in its light weight and versatility.Like science, good UI/UX design begins with empathy. It requires a designer to intimately understand their users. As we saw with my Wikipedia redesign, focusing solely on the artistic aspects of your designs will inevitably lead to neglecting some of your usersâ most important needs. An easy way to begin your designs with empathy is to conduct user interviews at the start of each project. Work with your clients or supervisors to identify your key user base and then contact people who identify similarly. Get to know your target audience by literally talking to them.
I mentioned earlier that occasionally Art has the power to empathize with and give a voice to underrepresented populations. I think thatâs a beautiful quality. But did Jackson Pollock take the time to connect with his intended audience, intimately understand their greatest needs, and provide solutions to their problems in a way that empathized with their physical and cognitive limitations? I never met the man, but Iâd guess he probably didnât.
3. Good design follows the scientific method. Some of the greatest works of art began not with a hypothesis, but with inspiration. And while itâs important for a designer to have several sources of design inspiration, itâs simply not practical for every single website or app you design to begin with inspiration. Iâm currently working with a client to design a financial reporting and aggregation tool. A product built by accountants, for accountants. No amount of time spent browsing Dribbble or watching sunsets will fill me with the monumental desire to design life-changing accounting software. Instead, good design should follow the scientific method.
Aside: Before I began my design business, I taught STEM classes at a middle school in Boston. So for this post, Iâll use the scientific method as taught to fifth graders. Some folks who studied the hard sciences in college might be familiar with more complex variants of the scientific method, but for design purposes, we donât need much more than a 5th grade understanding.
(An image of with each step of the Scientific Method written on an index card.) (An image of with each step of the Scientific Method written on an index card.) (An image of with each step of the Scientific Method written on an index card.) Good UI/UX Design follows the scientific method.The scientific method begins with a question. Remember that good UI/UX design solves problems. Your question should revolve around the problem youâre trying to solve. If, for example, your problem happens to be that users find it difficult to complete a form on your web application, your question could resemble âHow do I design a form with less friction?â
Research constitutes the scientific methodâs second step. The point here is to discern whether someone else has already solved our problem. Referring back to the poorly-converting form example, is there already an elegant solution for designing frictionless forms? If so, you can stop here. Study existing forms that convert at your target conversion rate and apply their techniques to your own forms. If, however, you face a previously unsolved problem, your research continues.
The second half of the research phase consists of user research. Talk to your users. Ask them what problems they perceive. Set up a screen-share session and observe your users attempt a form submission. Youâll pinpoint the exact instances of friction and thus narrow the problem.
Step three in the scientific method contains hypothesizing. Weâve identified a design problem by asking questions, weâve researched potential solutions to the problem and weâve researched why users encounter this problem. Now itâs time to brainstorm solutions. Thatâs solutionsssss, plural. A large number of beginner designers will stop here. Theyâll design one solution and call it a day. Theyâll send their single design to the client and collect their paycheck. But weâre only halfway through the scientific method so far. Stopping here severely limits the quality and efficacy of our designs (which could in turn limit the amount we charge for our designs).
The scientific methodâs fourth step involves testing your hypotheses. Youâve brainstormed several potential solutions and now itâs time to test them, in a round of user testing. Use Invision or some other prototyping tool to place your new designs in front of users. If you want to get real scientific, separate your participants into several groups: a control group who uses the old/problematic design, and a group for each of your newly designed potential solutions. (Note: this strategy becomes implausible for small projects with a limited supply of users willing to participate in testing. Just do the best you can with the resources you have.) Again, ask users what problems they perceive and set up a screen-share session to observe how they interact with your new designs.
Steps 5 and 6 are pretty simple: analyzing the data and drawing conclusions. After conducting your user testing, it should become clear which of your prototypes performed the best. Thatâs the one youâll want to tidy up and submit to your client. If it turns out that the old/problematic design performed better than any of your redesigns, thatâs perfectly okay. Simply repeat steps 3 and 4 until you have a design that works.
Good digital product design follows the scientific method. If you want to charge good money for your work, youâll need data and results to justify your rates. Adhering to the scientific method can equip you with that data. If you treat your designs like art, youâll find yourself wasting chunks of time looking for inspiration when you could be following an actionable plan to success.
4. Good design is not subjective. I foresee heavy criticism from artists for the following paragraphs. Iâm certain several folks who have attended art school or hold a music degree will tell me that art is very much not subjective. And they might be right; after all, it is possible to flunk out of art school.
However, when it comes to the art consumed by masses, personal taste dominates the market. For instance, someone who studied music at an advanced level might be able to explain why Punk Rock is overly simplified and takes less technical proficiency to master than some other genre. But at the end of the day, the guys from Green Day comprise some of the wealthiest people on the planet because they created art that millions of people subjectively enjoy. Similarly, the art that decorates my apartment I purchased out of subjective affinity. There exist no criteria or checklists for proving the quality of the paintings on my walls. I simply like the paintings.
Good design differs from art because massively successful designs are objectively good. In fact, UI/UX design can be measured against a set of criteria to determine its worth. A designâs success lies not in the personal preferences of its users; rather, a designâs success can be accurately predicted and measured based on whether it meets a set of standards.
(A scientist places an unknown substance into a machine for measurement.) (A scientist places an unknown substance into a machine for measurement.) (A scientist places an unknown substance into a machine for measurement.) Like science, good UI/UX Design is objective and its success can be measured. Photo by Satheesh Sankaran on Unsplash .Author and designer Michael Cummings makes the distinction that â[good] design is a craft of service, not self-expression.â He suggests that the key difference between design and art is the people it serves. Since most folks generally consider art as a means of expression, art tends to serve its creator. But since design strives to serve a set of users by solving a problem, it inherently bears an air of objectivity; the design either solves that problem or it doesnât.
Design is a craft of service, not self-expression. â Michael Cummings, UX design.com
Designer Bronwen Rees offers a similar argument for Toptal.com. She writes, âalthough a design outcome can be artful,â the design process shares very little in common with art. On one hand, Rees continues, art âaims to aesthetically express personal ideas or feelings through a particular medium.â Design, on the other hand, constitutes â the result of a number of decisions made by one or more designers trying to solve a specific problem relative to a user; it is then evaluated simply by how successful it is at solving that problem. If unsuccessful, then the design has failed.â
So if good UI/UX design is objective, and we can measure it, what criteria should we use for measuring our designs? How do we know if theyâre good?
The Short Answer: If your design solves the problems you intended to solve, itâs a good design.
The Medium Answer: In an article for the Interactive Design Foundation (the largest online design school in the world), author Euphemia Wong lists ten guidelines for successful user interface design. If a design canât meet a majority of these guidelines, you can objectively conclude the design will fail. I personally recommend bookmarking Wongâs article if youâre new to design and desire an actionable checklist for your designs.
The Long Answer: Don Norman, the man who coined the phrase âUser Experienceâ back when he worked at Apple, and Jakob Nielsen, another UX pioneer, built a free library of UI and UX resources and posted them to their website . The Nielsen Norman Group have compiled hundreds of heavily researched articles meant to provide digital product designers everywhere with the tools to craft highly successful interfaces and experiences. I recently read an article titled, â113 Design Guidelines for Homepage Usability,â which you can find here . Although an incredibly useful guide, the articleâs length can prove rather dizzying. If youâre a designer looking to up your skills, I highly recommend spending some time on the Nielsen Norman Group website. Youâll find endless resources and checklists for reviewing and improving your designs.
Good UI/UX design is a science because, like many other scientific fields, it aims for objectivity and its results can be measured. Although the design process can yield a profoundly artistic result, the design process constitutes an entirely scientific procedure.
5. Good design can be taught. Perhaps one of the longest debates in the art world, the question of whether art can be taught. I think a case can be made for both sides. A student can learn proper paintbrush techniques. A student can learn how to operate a camera. A student can learn music theory. But painting a masterpiece, capturing compelling images, and composing a truly remarkable piece of music often necessitates some level of intrinsic talent. Remarkable UI/UX Design, on the other hand, requires no natural-born genius. Just like the worldâs greatest scientists, the worldâs greatest designers acquired their skills through extensive study. To prove my point, letâs examine the work of two world-renowned scientists and two world-class design agencies.
First, letâs take a look at the careers of Neil deGrasse Tyson and Jennifer Doudna. Both of these scientists were born naturally gifted. Thereâs no disputing the inherent brilliance of each of these two scientists. But Tyson didnât come into this world with an intimate knowledge of astrophysics. He studied the heavens at Harvard, the University of Texas, and Columbia. He conducted research at Princeton. Tysonâs intellect? A natural born gift. Tysonâs familiarity with the cosmos? An acquired knowledge.
The same logic holds true for Jennifer Doudna, who won the 2020 Nobel prize in chemistry for her work in gene editing. Although Doudna has always been an incredibly gifted in an intellectual sense, she was not born with the knowledge that CRISPR-Cas9 could be used for programmable editing of genomes. Instead, she learned about biochemistry at Pomona College and Harvard Medical School.
(An Image of biochemist Jennifer Doudna) (An Image of biochemist Jennifer Doudna) (An Image of biochemist Jennifer Doudna) Jennifer Doudna, recipient of the 2020 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.Like remarkable scientists, great designers can acquire their skills through study. Anyone can internalize the criteria for good UI/UX design, and anyone can practice their craft until their designs meet those criteria. The design agencies Elegant Seagulls and Clay Agency exemplify the quality of output to which a designer can aspire, if they put in the effort.
Both Elegant Seagulls and Clay have won Webbies and Awwwards for their design innovation. But I can guarantee you that none of the designers on staff for either agency knew about the Rule of Thirds or how to build responsive websites from birth. Unlike historyâs greatest artists, the greatest designers honed their craft through study, practice, and trial & error.
UI/UX Designer Erik Kennedy (who has designed for folks like Amazon and Soylent) wrote an incredibly powerful article about his journey to mastering good design (and the specific techniques he learned and applies to every design). In the article, Kennedy mentions that the majority of his journey consisted of âbeing bad and then deliberately practicing.â He says good design can be learned through âcold, hard analysis.â
I learned [design] the same way Iâve learned any creative endeavor: cold, hard analysis â¦ from being bad and then deliberately practicing. â Erik Kennedy
Good design can be taught. In fact, learning constitutes the only way a designer can get good. When digital product designers treat their work as though itâs art, we snub the countless hours weâve spent studying, practicing, and failing as we worked our tails off to obtain our skills. Donât discredit your struggle by allowing your work to coalesce into a subjective art form. Treat your design work like the objective science it is.

The Medium Answer: In an article for the Interactive Design Foundation (the largest online design school in the world), author Euphemia Wong lists ten guidelines for successful user interface design. Although the design process can yield a profoundly artistic result, the design process constitutes an entirely scientific procedure.

ami:document.ami:content:
An emergency field hospital with tents customarily used for disaster relief has been opened in New Yorkâs Central Park, and across the globe, âsocial distancingâ has become part of our everyday behavior.
We are coming to grips with COVID-19, but it has caught us off guard. As most of the worldâs population is under some form of lockdown, we find ourselves in the middle of an unprecedented social experiment with many people working remotely and entire families staying home.
A global pandemic of this scale was inevitable. For years, we have been warned of the possibility by hundreds of health experts, and in 2015, Bill Gates talked about how unprepared we are in his TED talk . He grimly warned: âIf anything kills over 10 million people in the next few decades, itâs most likely to be a highly infectious virus rather than a war.â We are now faced with a challenge that has no parallel in peacetime this century.
(Image by Sumanley xulx from Pixabay )While most people manage to âkeep calm and carry on,â friction and frustration are inevitable living under such a crisis. But duress lays fertile ground for innovation, and during times such as these, eager designers and creatives canât help but see opportunities for improvement.
If we approached COVID-19 as a design problem, could we find innovative ways to apply design thinking and human-centered design principles to help soothe everyday frustrations and mitigate the most pressing issues? Drawing parallels between the problems of the global pandemic and those of product and service design, the similarities are obvious.
At the intersection of the innovatorâs mindset and creative thinking, we could explore ways to help the world deal with this and the next pandemic. Reaching into our designerâs toolkit, we could deploy the staples of our craft, including problem definition, ethnographic research, ideation, prototyping, and user testing. Taking advantage of recent innovations and the latest technology, we could run Design Sprints, focus on a specific problem, generate multiple solutions, build prototypes, and get rapid feedback.
The six phases of the design thinking process.The Design Thinking Process Applied to COVID-19 A global pandemic puts enormous stress on governments and healthcare services. Suddenly, there is a scramble to circulate the correct information and roll out products and services to deal with the crisis. These challenges bring together a blend of product design, experience design, and service design problems that are desperate for a solution, and design thinking can help.
Design thinking is a methodology that provides a solution-based approach to solving problems. It combines whatâs desirable from a human point of view with what is technologically feasible and economically viable. Itâs useful in tackling loosely defined, complex problems by understanding human needs.
Design thinking is unique compared with other forms of problem-solving methods in that itâs a non-linear process focused on delivering outcomes, rather than being focused on a precise problem definition. The design thinking process consists of five stages: empathize, define, ideate, prototype, and test. Each step needs to be given appropriate resources and the proper duration to create an end product that reliably meets user needs.
Information Clarity, Consistency, and Distribution The flow of information is essential to curbing a pandemic. While the virus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic was spreading, it took authorities several weeks to consolidate their messaging and make it consistent. With advanced technology, the distribution of information isnât the problem. Itâs transmitting the right information to the right people at the right time.
In times of crisis, there is an acute need for standardized, consistent, and effective information design. Principle four from the Nielsen Norman Groupâs 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design states: âUsers should not have to wonder whether different words, situations, or actions mean the same thing.â
To contain the outbreak, the UK government quickly moved to design clear, consistent messaging, taking advantage of the rule of three : â Stay at home. Protect the NHS. Save lives. â It was widely distributed via the internet and media. People received texts, got emails, and saw posters on the street, all of which have proved to be very effective.
Consistent government messages appeared across the internet and streets in the UK.Unfortunately, not all governments are created equal, and too little came too late from too many. Particularly when lives are at stake, clear and consistent instructions from healthcare services and authorities need to be out sooner rather than later.
In an ideal scenario, an emergency âdesign commissionâ with an army of volunteer designers and content strategists could spring into action to rapidly craft and test various designs. Taking the design thinking phases of empathize, define, and ideate, this rapid response team of designers could assist authorities with formulating the right kind of messaging.
During the final phase of design thinking: implementation, governments could text millions of people with new rules around social distancing with the help of mobile operators. Getting information out rapidly over a variety of channels would ensure people receive the right kind of information promptly.
More than 60 million people received coronavirus text alerts from the UK government during the COVID-19 crisis.The primary goal of content strategists and information designers working with healthcare services is not only to convey vital information but to reduce peopleâs âcognitive load.â Borrowed from cognitive psychology, it is a frequently used term in UX and describes the process where, unable to process an overload of critical information, the brain shuts down.
Information designers can observe the Laws of UX and apply two of its âgolden rulesâ to reduce cognitive load: Hickâs Law and Millerâs Law. Hickâs Law states that âthe time it takes to make a decision increases with the number and complexity of choices,â so minimalist, uncomplicated designs are best when people need to make a decision. For example, it could be applied to an infographic outlining whether to use facial masks or not.
A series of pictograms illustrate how to wash hands.In an extreme scenario, both of these laws could be violated simultaneously by confusing pictograms meant to convey vital information, i.e., presenting too many choices and asking people to remember too many things.
The third UX principle that could be adopted for powerful information design is the Von Restorff Effect , which can help people recall information more easily. It states that âitems that stand out from their peers are more memorable.â Designers can use the Von Restorff Effect to design effective, memorable information that needs to be conveyed quickly and convincingly.
The Psychology of Panic Buying Experts say hoarding essential supplies despite reassurances from experts that shortages of everyday household goods are unlikely is motivated by a natural human reaction to stress and uncertainty.
When crises occur, people quite naturally want to regain control. We tend to run with the herd, thinking: âIf everyone else is buying toilet paper, hand sanitizers, and pasta, I should probably do the same.â
How can stores prevent or at least get ahead of this kind of behavior? Reflecting on the principles of UX design, itâs about âknowing your user.â Becoming keenly aware of previous events, patterns, and behaviors that lead to the raiding of aisles in supermarkets and pharmacies could mitigate the problem.
A supermarket in Australia in the midst of panic buying.Aligning the panic-shopping phenomenon with the user interface heuristic âvisibility of system status,â clear signage throughout the shopping experience could curtail the rush to stock up on essentials. Governments could raise awareness through the media and send uniform signage to grocery stores to calm nerves and inform shoppers that there is plenty to go around.
If there is a principle that is sacred to UX designers, itâs âknow your user.â After all, how can we design something for people without in-depth, detailed knowledge of them? Don Norman , co-founder and Principal Emeritus of Nielsen Norman Group
Supermarket signage and social media postings in the UK that help discourage panic buying.Product and Service Design in the Age of COVID-19 Effective solutions are desperately needed to a myriad of problems foisted on the world by COVID-19. As a result, the pandemic is powering innovation on an atypical scale and pace not normally considered. Apart from PPEs (personal protective equipment), hospital beds, and face shields, ventilators are in short supply, which has sparked an astounding number of design breakthroughs. And thatâs just one area where necessity has proved itself to be the mother of invention.
Innovation is now recognized as the single most important ingredient in any modern economy. Tom Kelley, IDEO Partner
Self-diagnosis at home, monitoring those who are infected, widespread testing, and contact tracing are just a few design problems that need solving. Dealing with emergent mental health issues, panic buying, and social distancing caused by lockdowns is another. Endless design problems with unique challenges present themselves during global crises, and exciting design opportunities abound.
Fusing advanced technology with design thinking, designers have an opportunity to bring forth many innovative products and services.
Design Thinking in Healthcare: Test, Trace, and Treat In the battle to contain the contagion, employing the test, trace, and treat approach is unavoidable. Widespread testing and contact tracing are needed to identify and alert people who have come into contact with a person infected with the coronavirus.
Putting into practice the user-centered design process, designers could brainstorm new ideas with the â how might we â method. It would require us to accept that we donât currently know the answer and foster a collaborative approach to solving it. IDEO calls it â challenge mapping ,â which is very similar to the 5 Whys method for problem-solving (developed at Toyota in the 1930s).
For example, currently, home test kits are not reliable for testing for novel coronavirus infection. But the steps in the design thinking process could be applied to make them ready for the next one.
Under empathizing and defining, we can understand the problem; with ideation and prototyping, we can explore the most cost-effective way to make them; and with testing and implementation, we can refine and deliver an effective solution. In this way, millions of home test kits could be designed, prototyped, and tested.
A contact-tracing app.Mobile apps and big data are ideal partners for contact tracing. When people develop symptoms, how can they know if itâs COVID-19? An AI-powered COVID-19 symptom checker app could âlistenâ to coughs and breathing, as well as measure body temperature and heart rate via an external wristband. Comparing results with large sets of previous data, it would come up with a diagnosis. Once the symptoms are confirmed, the app can then advise users on an appropriate course of action.
Looking at social distancing, apps could be designed that alert people if theyâre getting too close to someone. It could be wearable tech, such as a chest camera, that would send an audible alert to their mobile device (or their earphones).
Social distancing could be made easier with wearable technology.COVID-19 and Mental Health â Living in Isolation As authorities race to stem the spread of the coronavirus by shuttering everything we take for granted, some experts fear the consequences on peopleâs mental health, and the longer a quarantine continues, the greater the effect.
Experts say that depression, anxiety, and suicides typically emerge from traumatic events, such as widespread lockdowns and the uncertainty of the pandemic. The impact is worse for those with existing mental health conditions, the elderly, the vulnerable, and the self-isolating.
Eight to 10 days after they were quarantined due to the spread of COVID-19, more than half the participants in a recent study reported the adverse psychological effects of the outbreak as âmoderate or severe.â Can design thinking address peopleâs protracted isolation and look for ways to alleviate mental stress?
We can take steps from the design thinking process and approach problems from the userâs perspective: empathize with sufferers and ideate solutions. Healthcare services could support the availability of high-quality, remote counseling by therapists, psychiatric nurses, and doctors. However, the ease of use (usability) of these digital services is crucial, as well as the simplicity of making an appointment.
For many people, talking to friends and family over video calls helps. However, according to Jakob Nielsen of the Nielsen Norman Group, the elderly are typically not tech-savvy users and âneed dramatically simplified softwareâ that works with a push of a button. For them, making a video call needs to be almost as simple as using a lightswitch.
To help detect depression, Massachusetts Institute of Technology researchers have recently developed an AI system that can detect if a person is suffering from depression by analyzing their speech patterns. Such an AI system can power a mobile app that monitors a personâs speaking patterns, detects mental distress, and sends an alert to doctors. It could prove especially useful for those who canât get to a doctor for an initial diagnosis due to distance, cost, or a lack of awareness that something may be wrong.
Designing Better Personal Protective Equipment When stepping out of home isolation, protection is on everyoneâs mind. During lockdowns, people still need to get essential supplies, pick up medication, and get some exercise.
As designers approach the new norms and apply design thinking to personal protection, a window of opportunity opens up for design innovation. We can empathize, define, ideate, prototype, test, and implement. For example, designers could envision washable gloves made of comfortable material that offer sufficient protection and would become part of our daily protective wear.
For those with a smartwatch, using haptic vibration, apps could sound an alert as the wearer is about to touch their face. Fashionable face masks that are easy to manage yet block airborne viruses could be designed.
Fashion face masks (AusAir ).The lack of personal protective equipment for medical professionals is prompting design innovation at an unprecedented scale. In any healthcare system, there are not only the patients to consider but their families, the doctors, nurses, and other support personnel. A holistic system including all its components needs to be considered in order to see where design can help.
Itâs putting the person, the human at the centre of what you do. Because no matter what industry or sector youâre in, thereâs a human in there somewhere, so just anticipate and consider their needs. Kathryn Townsend, Head of Customer & Client Accessibility, Barclays UK
During the ideation phase in design thinking, itâs unlikely the ultimate solution to the problem will be discovered. The point is to come up with as many ideas as possible, sort through them to find the best ones (which will likely be some combination of user needs, practicality, cost-effectiveness, and other factors specific to the project), and then figure out which ideas should move on to the next step: prototyping.
Dr. Diana Sedler, a periodontist, puts on a 3D-printed mask designed at her familyâs business (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez).Challenging assumptions is key to defining what is or isnât a viable solution that can lead to innovative ideas. The idea is to try everything, even if some turn out to be duds.
I have not failed. Iâve just found 10,000 ways that wonât work. Thomas Edison
As intensive care units are overwhelmed, there is an acute shortage of ventilators. Some ventilator manufacturers are forming partnerships with various firms and working around the clock to make them as fast as possible. Hope is also riding on smaller design labs that could make ventilators more quickly.
With ideation and prototyping, a team led by University of Oxford professors along with a student and professors from Kingâs College of London have defined a simple, safe, and scalable ventilator design that meets the strict specifications for use with patients. The design exploits off-the-shelf components and equipment with parts that can be produced using 3D printing, cutting costs dramatically.
âIn less than two weeks, the students, researchers, and academics driving this project have developed into a highly structured and efficient team, brainstormed a prototype, and won government backing,â professor Mark Thompson of Oxford said.
The OxVent, developed in less than two weeks (University of Oxford ).Contactless Everything Is King Naturally, people fear contact with anything when a tap on a screen or keypad can cause a fatal infection. Touch-based UIs are not favored, and paying with cash isnât permitted in many grocery stores. Out are ATMs, supermarket keypads, and vending machines; in are contactless transportation passes and payment terminals where people can use contactless cards, ApplePay, and Google Pay.
And then there is radar tech like Googleâs Project Soli for contactless interactions.
Project Soli is developing a new interaction sensor using radar technology. The sensor tracks sub-millimeter motions at high speed and accuracy. It fits onto a chip, can be produced at scale, and built into small devices and everyday objects. Soli is a miniature radar that understands human motions at various scales: from the tap of a finger to body movements.
Googleâs Project Soli , âan interactive hemisphere that can sense and understand movements.âContactless payment terminals are already here, but soon, using radar-powered motion sensors, contactless UIs should be possible for everything from ATMs to vending machines. Interacting may be slower with these UIs, but âcontactless-modesâ will be safer to use. When there is no longer a need, systems can switch back to touch-based interactions.
Shopping for essentials in contactless stores would be a boon during global pandemics. Computer vision, sensor fusion, and deep learning systems can enable checkout-free shopping experiences. Are checkout-free stores like Amazon Go Grocery ahead of their time?
An Amazon Go Grocery store in New York (Fabiana Buontempo/Business Insider ).Data Visualization and Analysis Putting cities under lockdown is not enough. Testing, contact tracing, home isolation, and rapid treatment are vital-all of which generate a lot of unstructured data. A sea of data coming in is good, but data alone doesnât speak and doesnât help make informed decisions. Itâs tantamount to drinking from a firehose.
Policymakers and hospital leaders need to make informed decisions based on facts backed by data. For systems to function well, we not only need data but more importantly, robust data analysis and data visualization tools. Again, â visibility of system status â takes on vital importance. Patterns need to be identified, the spread of the virus visualized, and disease conditions monitored 24/7.
To facilitate better decision-making, researchers and startups are using artificial intelligence and other technologies to predict where the virus might appear next and how fast it will spread. These AI tools may use advanced technology and algorithms, but many of them suffer from poor usability. They need to be well-designed, present data efficiently, and communicate complexity with clarity through sophisticated data visualization.
UX designers have an opportunity to step in and make improvements. Once again, they can turn to the design thinking process: define the problem, ideate solutions, prototype, test, and implement the next generation of data visualization tools.
ami:document.ami:description: The six phases of the design thinking process.The Design Thinking Process Applied to COVID-19 A global pandemic puts enormous stress on governments and healthcare services. In an ideal scenario, an emergency âdesign commissionâ with an army of volunteer designers and content strategists could spring into action to rapidly craft and test various designs. Taking the design thinking phases of empathize, define, and ideate, this rapid response team of designers could assist authorities with formulating the right kind of messaging.

La sociÃ©tÃ© amÃ©ricaine Coinbase,Â plateforme d'achats et de ventes de cryptomonnaies comme le bitcoin, a annoncÃ© jeudi qu'elle fera ses premiers pas Ã la Bourse de New York le 14 avril, sous le symbole COIN (piÃ¨ce de monnaie en franÃ§ais).
L'entrÃ©e de Coinbase Ã Wall Street sur la plateforme Nasdaq sera une premiÃ¨re pour une entreprise de devises virtuelles.
Comme prÃ©vu, le groupe utilisera la mÃ©thode de la cotation directe , et non une introduction en Bourse classique, et ne rÃ©cupÃ¨rera en consÃ©quence pas d'argent frais.
> Lire : Pourquoi les sociÃ©tÃ©s de la Tech optent pour la cotation directe
UnÂ chiffre d'affaires Ã +136% en 2020 pour atteindre 1,14 milliard Mais les actionnaires dÃ©jÃ prÃ©sents Ã son capital - les fondateurs, les employÃ©s et les investisseurs historiques - pourront vendre leurs participations sur le marchÃ©. Ce processus a dÃ©jÃ Ã©tÃ© utilisÃ© par Spotify, Slack, Palantir ou Roblox.
Un prix de rÃ©fÃ©rence sera fourni la veille au soir de l'opÃ©ration.
La plateforme a Ã©tÃ© fondÃ©e en 2012 Ã San Francisco et fournit des services d'achats, de ventes et de gestion de portefeuilles de cryptomonnaies.
Le groupe est en pleine croissance : son chiffre d'affaires s'est envolÃ© de 136% en 2020 pour atteindre 1,14 milliard de dollars. Et la plateforme a gagnÃ© de l'argent l'an dernier: 322 millions de dollars aprÃ¨s une perte de 30 millions en 2019.
Coinbase recensait 43 millions d'utilisateurs particuliers fin 2020.
La sociÃ©tÃ© estimait alors avoir sur sa plateforme 90 milliards de dollars d'actifs, une somme tirÃ©e par l'envolÃ©e du bitcoin dont le prix a quadruplÃ© en 2020 avant d'exploser depuis le dÃ©but de l'annÃ©e.
Les prix d'autres cryptomonnaies comme Ethereum ou Litecoin ont aussi bondi ces derniers mois.
Lire aussi : Elon Musk rend possible l'achat d'une Tesla en bitcoin, pour prouver l'usage
Sur le mÃªme sujet - (Le cours du bitcoin a depasse 60.000 dollars) Le bitcoin ou le vide symbolique - (Musk: maintenant possible d'acheter une tesla avec des bitcoins) Elon Musk rend possible l'achat d'une Tesla en bitcoin, pour prou... - (bitcoin) Un kilo d'or pour un bitcoin, que vaut la comparaison des deux ac... - (bitcoin) Le Bitcoin et les complotistes
Abonnez-vous Ã partir de 1â¬ Suivez La Tribune Partageons les informations Ã©conomiques, recevez nos newsletters
Je m'inscris RÃ©agir
Recevoir un email si quelqu'un rÃ©pond Ã mon commentaire. Envoyer commentaire Votre email ne sera pas affichÃ© publiquement Tous les champs sont obligatoires
Commentaires Quand l'Europe se rÃ©veillera a Ã©crit le 02/04/2021 Ã 16:08 : Va-t-on laisser nos monnaies nationales se faire uberiser. Est-ce que demain, je devrais payer en Bitcoin, Liteoin, Ethereum, DigiCoin ma baguette de pain. Est-ce que le Bitcoin de viendra un Ã©tat souverain ? Je ne vois pas la valeur qu'apportent ses cryptomonnaies Ã la sociÃ©tÃ©, si ce n'est l'enrichissement personnel de quelques visionnaires. Pourquoi payer sa TESLA en Bitcoin et pas en dollar ? Est-ce que demain, un "Ã©tat Bitcoin" sera capable d'agir et d'investir du Bitcoin pour supporter un pays en crise. Je ne crois pas. Ces monnaies alternatives sont comme Uber lors de son lancement qui visait Ã dÃ©rÃ©guler le marchÃ© des taxis. Bilans des courses, les uber-drivers deviennent maintenant des salariÃ©s comme les autres. Je suis preneur de comprendre ce qu'apporte une crypto-monnaie par rapport Ã une monnaie classique, si ce n'est une forme d'Ã©vasion fiscale et de shadow monnaie.

ami:document.ami:content:
Understanding how we get to know people in our personal life can teach us how to be better designers
Photo by Tatiana Vavrikova from PexelsFor my first assignment at university, I was assigned a partner, and told to come to the next lesson with a gift for them and then explain to the rest of the class why I had chosen it. I didnât realise at the time, but I was about to be taught a lesson that has stayed with me ever since.
It didnât seem like a difficult task, so I neglected it until the day the assignment was due. That morning however, when I started thinking about what to give my partner, I realised I had been set some serious homework. I didnât know anything about them. What did they have already? What were they interested in? What made them laugh?
Ten minutes before the lesson started, I found myself in the university shop buying a notebook (because my partner was a student) and chocolate (because they were a human). Turning up to class, I felt a little ashamed of my efforts. My first week of university had been spent listening to teachers talk about how great designers create value for people by understanding latent needs, and here I was â about to present the most unimaginative gifts imaginable. I think my embarrassment during the presentation was obvious. The teacher didnât need to say anything because the message was clearâ¦ If I wanted to create value for people, I would have to get to know them first.
Homer showing that he only really knows himselfWe thrive as innovators when we have a vivid picture of the people we are designing for in our minds. On the Master of Scale podcast , Airbnb founder Brian Chesky discusses how getting to know his customers is where his companyâs success stemmed from, âItâs really hard to get even 10 people to love anything. But itâs not hard if you spend a ton of time with them.â Chesky was so committed to learning about his customers that if you were an early adopter of his service, itâs likely you would have met him. âWe had their addresses and we say, âKnock knock. Hello. Hey, this is Brian, Joe, weâre founders and we just want to meet you.â â
When you know your customer you have a distinct advantage. Imagine if I was set the same gift-giving task but with a close friend. It would be much easier because I know what they own already; I know what makes them laugh; I know what music they actually enjoy listening to (despite what they might tell others). Because I have a rich image of them in my mind, itâs easy to predict their reaction to potential gifts. Spending time with people helps us build this picture.
But what specifically happens during that time that helps us get to know them?
The Stages of Learning About a PersonOne of the leading psychologists in the field of personality psychology, Professor J. D. Mayer, says that in order to form a vivid representation of a person in our mind, we must go through five stages of learning about them. This process starts with hearing about someoneâs existence (learning from afar); meeting them and forming initial impressions (first impressions); witnessing their behaviour over time (ongoing observation); testing our understanding of their character (testing and checking); and then ending with a reliable representation (lasting memories). Why this is interesting for innovators is because Mayerâs framework doesnât just describe what we go through naturally in our personal lives, but also what we go through during customer research.
Stages of Learning About a Person, Mayer, 2014 Stage 1: Learning from AfarHearing of a personâs reputation and gaining context about their environment
In our personal life, we often aim to get an understanding of people before we meet them â essentially to see if itâs worth the effort of getting to know them. This is done by listening to what other people say about them, or these days, by looking at their social media profiles.
In research projects, we can start in a similar way. In this case, we are making sure we identify the right people to start talking to. This is done by asking the client what they already know about their customers from past projects, and by studying existing consumer reports . This helps form an understanding of some of the basic facts about the customer and their environment; their age, gender, socioeconomic group and the trends that may be affecting their life.
Stage 2: First ImpressionsAttending to a personâs outward appearance and other observable characteristics and signals
To find out if a person is someone we are going to get on with, we meet them and see first-hand how they present themselves to the world. From the first meeting onwards, we will do this by listening to how they talk and by observing their body language. Are they shy? funny? serious? What do they like to talk about? What do they think about certain topics?
In design research, we also start to deepen our knowledge by directly interacting with the customer. In this case, not to figure out if we like them, but to figure out if there is potential for them to like us. Through exploratory interviews and surveys , we start to understand how they see themselves, their attitudes to the world, and their current experiences in it.
Stage 3: Ongoing ObservationMonitoring a personâs actions and examining any discrepancies between their appraisal and their behavior
By the end of stage 2 we know some facts about a person, and how they see themselves and their world. However, we donât yet know the deeper characteristics that influence their behaviour. By spending more time with them and observing how they act in different environments, for example, at a party vs. a nice restaurant we begin to learn this.
During this stage in design research, we also start building mental models of customer behaviour so we can begin to predict it. To achieve this we may shadow our customer, or run diary studies . We do these activities because unlike interviewing and surveying, it shows us things customers are unable to explicitly share about themselves.
Stage 4: Testing and CheckingTesting our predictions about a personâs behavior, changing how we act with the target and seeing how the target acts in response
To ensure our understanding of a person is correct we need to test the mental models we have of them. For example, if we think our new friend is a bit straightlaced, we can test this by asking them to sneak out of work for a cheeky pint with us. If they say yes, we reform our model of them in our head to incorporate this behaviour.
With customers, we build prototypes to test our predictions about them. These can be low fidelity at this point as we are focusing on testing customers needs rather than design details. An example of this might be setting up a fake landing page and tracking the engagement to test our assumption that the customer has a need for our service.
Stage 5: Lasting MemoriesHaving key recollections of the person that we can readily call to mind
By this stage we have the feeling that we know someone well. Even if they are not with us, we can imagine what that friend might say or do if they were.
By this point in a design project, the team should also have a working model of the customer (or customers); one that incorporates all the findings from the previous stages: basic facts, attitudes, behaviours and tested assumptions. To share this with the wider team they can create personas . Itâs important to note that personas are not set in stone and should continue to evolve over time by revisiting these stages.
Get to know your customerIf you are wondering how well you know your customer, set yourself the task of buying them a surprise gift. If you are struggling to think of anything beyond the generic, you probably need to learn more about them. Using Mayerâs framework, you can see what activities you need to do to deepen your knowledge of your customer. The reward will be worth the effort because whatâs true in our personal lives is also true in design: itâs the people who know us best that are able to bring us the most value.
âI didnât ask for itâ¦ I just wanted itâ

ami:document.ami:content:
Thereâs been a huge focus over the last decade of getting user feedback early and often, thanks to the success of the lean startup movement and tech giants such as Amazon and Google. This has been great, and without doubt raised the quality bar for modern digital products, but how do you make sure youâre staying laser focussed on your users all of the time, not just at the points where youâre getting feedback? Here is some practical advice.
Product managers and designers have to be best friends
If theyâre not on the same wavelength, then Iâm afraid itâs not going to work. Product needs to involve design right from the start, so that they all get the vision and context first hand. Product managers need to be able to articulate clear objectives and metrics to give designers the space to come up with creative solutions.
Think hard, so that you can get your UX as right as you can first time
Yes, youâre going to get real user feedback as early as possible but itâs important that the feedback is on your very best effort. Iâve worked with lots of larger companies where apathy has set in after a design workshop and the team have settled with whatever the least controversial design route is. âWeâll find out if it doesnât work when we AB test itâ is just a lazy approach to me. You should only select your very best option(s) because they are going to take effort to design, prototype or build. You really need to think hard about the user experience, not necessarily longer, but harder!
Get into the mind of the most impatient person you know
A lot of product managers will talk about designing for a parent or grandparent, as theyâre unlikely to be as technically literate as you. Not bad advice, but I think itâs better to design for the most impatient person you know. They probably are technically literate but just want to get their stuff done as quickly as possible. People want to do stuff quickly in the real world, but they rarely have that pressure in a usability lab. If you can, try and get feedback from your impatient friend with a prototype. Impatient people will usually be very direct, swear lots and probably insult you, but theyâll give great feedback.
Optimise for the most important jobs for your target user
Seems obvious, but ruthlessly focussing on helping your users get their core job done and eliminating things that get in their way is vital. Itâs also a great way of helping you prioritise when your product starts to mature â how does the shiny new feature youâre building help your user get their core job done? If it doesnât, then it may be doing more harm than good.
Concentrate on the majority of your users
In larger companies where there are lots of stakeholders itâs easy to give undue weighting to edge cases, just because a particular stakeholder cares about them. Sure, your product needs to handle the edge cases, but it doesnât need to expose minor features with the same weighting as core functionality.
Look at this early WhatsApp example. Iâm guessing well over 95% of people will just tap on âContinueâ.
The edge cases are covered, there are links to explain the subscription and ad policy, but Iâm thinking only a handful of users will tap on these. Most of them will just want to get started and message their friends. WhatsApp have placed an appropriate level of emphasis on the buttons and links.
Text matters
If you have a copyrighter on the team, thatâs excellent. Often it falls to the product manager to write all of the text that appears on the product. If it does, then this needs to be taken very, very seriously. Using the right wording can make the difference between something that people can use right away and something that causes lots of confusion. Do it properly and create a document articulating your tone of voice, with examples, before writing your copy.
Everyoneâs a new user at the start
Everyone will go through your sign up journey so you need to make this as easy and frictionless as you possibly can. If they have problems the first time, theyâre unlikely to ever come back again, so your first use experience deserves lots of attention.
If you can do without it, you probably should
Generally the less you have on your page or screen the easier itâs going to be for your users. Itâs very easy to add too much functionality and features, less is usually more. You shouldnât be dogmatic about this, there are always situations where an extra screen or more guidance text makes sense.
Using these techniques will help you build more user focussed products. They donât in any way replace frequent prototyping and user testing, but they will help it be more effective.

Il souhaite Ã©galement voir "ouvrir un nouveau chapitre pour la reconstruction de l'unitÃ© nationale".Â

ami:document.ami:content:
What we say: âI like where youâre going, but I also wonder if we should exploreâ¦â
What we mean: âI donât like where youâre going.â
What ends up happening: The designer, who was clearly going in the wrong direction, is never clearly told they were wrong, or what was wrong about it. A whole generation of designers grow up thinking they have always been right. And canât understand when they end up receiving negative feedback later on.
What we say: âWhat weâre showing here is just a high-level overview of what weâve been exploring in the last two weeks, of course this will keep evolving.â
What we mean: âWe were not brave enough to make any decisions and/or to clearly state them on a slide. And although we had two weeks we were not thorough enough to finalize what we started. So weâll just do a whole presentation avoiding strong point of views that could hurt our relationship in case you disagree with what weâre saying.â
What ends up happening: The work gets pushed two extra weeks.
What we say: âWeâve run some informal user testing sessions here in the office, and found out people were having a hard time identifying with what was on the screen.â
What we mean: âI showed it to the guy who sits next to me and he didnât like it.â
What ends up happening: Nothing. Really.
What we say: âI hear what youâre saying. We can definitely explore your suggestion as we refine the designs.â
What we mean: âI donât like your idea, sorry. Iâll pretend I try to incorporate your suggestions, and then Iâll come up with some random excuse for why it didnât work out.â
What ends up happening: Not a single pixel is moved.
Now in all honesty: indirect speech can help us feel better in the short term and avoid confrontational situations, but has a negative effect in the long run. Design is a team sport â and as any other team sport it requires trust and honesty amongst players. Naming a bad feeling what it really is forces you to confront it, and forces you, as a team, to learn how to overcome it.
Less euphemisms. More maturity. Please.
This article is part of journey : stories about the amazing ride of being a designer.
Fabricio Teixeira
Designer at Work & Co, Founder of UX Collective â http://twitter.com/fabriciot
