ami:document.ami:content:
Le sÃ©lectionneur des champions du monde 2018 a dÃ©voilÃ© un groupe de 26 joueurs pour la rÃ©ception de l'Ukraine, le 24 mars au Stade de France, et le double dÃ©placement Ã Noursoultan et Sarajevo, les 28 et 31 mars contre le Kazakhstan et la Bosnie-HerzÃ©govine.Â
C'est trois de plus que les 23 autorisÃ©s sur la feuille de match (les joueurs surnumÃ©raires restent en tribunes), de faÃ§on Ã anticiper tout forfait Ã©ventuel liÃ© Ã des cas de Covid-19, une mÃ©saventure rÃ©currente depuis un an.Â
Sauf contamination ou blessure, les incontournables Hugo Lloris, Paul Pogba, Antoine Griezmann, Olivier Giroud et Kylian MbappÃ© seront sans surprise lundi Ã Clairefontaine pour le dÃ©but du rassemblement, deux jours avant d'affronter la "Zbirna" dirigÃ©e par l'ex-Ballon d'Or Andriy Shevchenko.Â
(L'Express Abo) Offre limitÃ©e. 2 mois pour 1â¬ sans engagement Je m'abonne
Ils y retrouveront notamment Ousmane DembÃ©lÃ©, l'ailier gauche du FC Barcelone qui n'a plus mis les pieds dans le centre d'entraÃ®nement des Bleus depuis novembre 2018.Â
- Areola de retour -Â
Depuis, le champion du monde de 23 ans a enchaÃ®nÃ© les blessures musculaires, les longues absences et les performances en dents de scie au BarÃ§a, avant de redevenir le dribbleur percutant pour lequel le club catalan avait investi plus de 125 millions d'euros Ã l'Ã©tÃ© 2017.Â
"Depuis plusieurs semaines, il enchaÃ®ne les matches, il a retrouvÃ© ses capacitÃ©s athlÃ©tiques, avec toujours cette capacitÃ© Ã faire des diffÃ©rences", a justifiÃ© Deschamps jeudi lors d'une confÃ©rence de presse au siÃ¨ge de la FÃ©dÃ©ration Ã Paris.Â
Un autre revenant retrouve Clairefontaine au meilleur moment: NdombÃ©lÃ©, 24 ans, profite de ses performances remarquÃ©es avec Tottenham et de l'absence de Corentin Tolisso (Bayern Munich), griÃ¨vement blessÃ© Ã une cuisse, pour revenir sous le maillot bleu plus d'un an aprÃ¨s sa derniÃ¨re convocation, sans jouer, en novembre 2019.Â
Thomas Lemar, le champion du monde de 25 ans, revient aussi pour la premiÃ¨re fois depuis cette date. AprÃ¨s un passage Ã vide, l'ex-milieu de Caen et Monaco affiche un niveau "plus consistant depuis plusieurs semaines" avec l'AtlÃ©tico Madrid, qui l'avait recrutÃ© pour un montant record de 72 M d'EUR en 2018, selon Deschamps.Â
C'est aussi en novembre 2019 que le gardien parisien prÃªtÃ© Ã Fulham Alphonse Areola (28 ans), rappelÃ© jeudi, a vu les Bleus pour la derniÃ¨re fois.Â
- "Pas de condamnÃ©s" -Â
Le "come-back" des quatre joueurs tombe Ã pic dans l'optique de l'Euro (11 juin-11 juillet), initialement prÃ©vu Ã l'Ã©tÃ© 2020 mais reportÃ© d'un an en raison de la pandÃ©mie. La liste de mars devrait en effet grandement ressembler Ã celle des vingt-trois joueurs retenus pour le Championnat d'Europe, que "DD" a dit vouloir dÃ©voiler "fin mai".Â
BlessÃ© dimanche avec Leipzig, le dÃ©fenseur central Dayot Upamecano est contraint de faire l'impasse en mars, mais le nÃ©o-international de 22 ans, conserve nÃ©anmoins une chance de disputer le tournoi paneuropÃ©en. Â
Ce sera plus compliquÃ© pour Houssem Aouar, Jonathan IkonÃ© et Eduardo Camavinga. Les trois milieux prometteurs, dÃ©jÃ appelÃ©s chez les A mais absents cette fois, ont Ã©tÃ© convoquÃ©s lundi par Sylvain Ripoll pour disputer la premiÃ¨re phase de l'Euro-Espoirs, fin mars en Hongrie.Â
"Il n'y a pas de condamnÃ©, il vaut mieux Ãªtre dans la liste de mai", a toutefois nuancÃ© "DD". "Les absents n'ont pas forcÃ©ment tort", a-t-il insistÃ©.Â
Parmi les "absents" de mars, figurent notamment les champions du monde Steven Nzonzi et Nabil Fekir, ainsi que le jeune attaquant Marcus Thuram (23 ans), auteur d'un premier rassemblement prometteur en novembre avant de traverser une pÃ©riode plus compliquÃ©e avec MÃ¶nchengladbach.Â
En raison de la pandÃ©mie de Covid-19, la Fifa a assoupli ses rÃ¨gles de convocation des joueurs pour la prochaine trÃªve internationale, autorisant les clubs Ã retenir leurs footballeurs si une quarantaine est obligatoire au retour. Mais Ã en croire Deschamps, cela ne devrait poser aucun problÃ¨me aux Bleus.Â
"Les joueurs auront l'obligation de venir directement Ã Clairefontaine (depuis leurs clubs). Ensuite, on se dÃ©place en vol charter et le retour au club se fera de la mÃªme faÃ§on", a dÃ©clarÃ© le sÃ©lectionneur, Ã©voquant des "accords avec les grands championnats" oÃ¹ Ã©voluent les FranÃ§ais pour qu'ils soient immÃ©diatement "disponibles" Ã leur retour en club.Â

La liste de mars devrait en effet grandement ressembler Ã celle des vingt-trois joueurs retenus pour le Championnat d'Europe, que "DD" a dit vouloir dÃ©voiler "fin mai".

ami:document.ami:content:
"Nous dÃ©fendrons nos propres intÃ©rÃªts et nous travaillerons avec (les AmÃ©ricains) aux conditions qui nous seront avantageuses", a ensuite insistÃ© Vladimir Poutine.Â
Au-delÃ des Ã©changes de piques, Moscou a clairement soulignÃ© que les remarques de M. Biden relevaient de l'inacceptable.Â
Fait inÃ©dit depuis 1998, le ministÃ¨re russe des Affaires Ã©trangÃ¨res a rappelÃ© son ambassadeur aux Etats-Unis pour des consultations sur l'avenir de la relation russo-amÃ©ricaine, plongÃ©e dans "l'impasse".Â
Car, selon l'ambassade russe Ã Washington, les "dÃ©clarations irrÃ©flÃ©chies de responsables amÃ©ricains risquent d'entraÃ®ner l'effondrement de relations dÃ©jÃ excessivement conflictuelles".Â
- "Prix Ã payer" -Â
Le Kremlin a lui dÃ©noncÃ© des propos qui dÃ©montrent que M. Biden "ne veut clairement pas amÃ©liorer les relations avec notre pays".Â
Seul signe jusqu'ici de dÃ©sescalade, le dÃ©partement d'Etat amÃ©ricain a assurÃ© Ã l'AFP qu'il ne prÃ©voyait pas de rappeler son propre reprÃ©sentant Ã Moscou.Â
Dans un entretien mercredi Ã la chaÃ®ne ABC, en plus de sa rÃ©ponse affirmative dÃ©peignant Vladimir Poutine en "tueur", M. Biden a voulu taper du point sur la table face au dirigeant russe.Â
Il a dit vouloir lui faire "payer" l'ingÃ©rence dans les Ã©lections amÃ©ricaines de 2016 et 2020. Moscou a toujours dÃ©menti ces accusations.Â
Vladimir Poutine "en paiera les consÃ©quences", a prÃ©venu Joe Biden, avant de rÃ©pÃ©ter, aprÃ¨s une relance: "Vous verrez bientÃ´t le prix qu'il va payer".Â
Ces propos ont Ã©tÃ© qualifiÃ©s par le prÃ©sident de la chambre basse du Parlement russe, Viatcheslav Volodine, d'"insulte" aux Russes et d'"attaque" contre son pays.Â
Un vice-prÃ©sident de la chambre haute, Konstantin Kossatchev, a lui demandÃ© "des explications et des excuses".Â
Les relations russo-amÃ©ricaines en particulier, et russo-occidentales en gÃ©nÃ©ral, sont dÃ©lÃ©tÃ¨res depuis des annÃ©es : annexion de la CrimÃ©e, guerre en Ukraine, conflit en Syrie ou encore l'empoisonnement et l'emprisonnement de l'opposant AlexeÃ¯ Navalny...Â
- CoopÃ©ration naissante menacÃ©e -Â
De multiples trains de sanctions et contre-sanctions ont Ã©tÃ© adoptÃ©s en consÃ©quence. Le gouvernement amÃ©ricain a annoncÃ© mercredi encore qu'il Ã©tendait les restrictions d'exportation de produits sensibles vers la Russie.Â
Jeudi, le G7 a lui une fois de plus dÃ©noncÃ© "l'occupation" de la CrimÃ©e par la Russie.Â
M. Poutine a rÃ©pliquÃ© Ã Joe Biden lors d'une visio-confÃ©rence avec des reprÃ©sentants de la sociÃ©tÃ© civile de cette pÃ©ninsule.Â
Le prÃ©sident Biden affiche depuis son arrivÃ©e Ã la Maison Blanche en janvier une grande fermetÃ© Ã l'Ã©gard du Kremlin, par opposition avec la bienveillance souvent reprochÃ©e Ã son prÃ©dÃ©cesseur Donald Trump jusque dans son camp rÃ©publicain.Â
Mais la brusque dÃ©gradation des rapports russo-amÃ©ricains depuis l'interview de mercredi pourrait menacer la coopÃ©ration naissante sur des dossiers d'intÃ©rÃªt commun.Â
L'exemple le plus marquant a encore Ã©tÃ© citÃ© par M. Biden mercredi, Ã savoir le prolongement en dÃ©but d'annÃ©e du traitÃ© de limitation des arsenaux nuclÃ©aires New Start.Â
D'autres sujets sur lesquels Russes et AmÃ©ricains tablaient sur des compromis pragmatiques sont le nuclÃ©aire iranien, les pourparlers de paix en Afghanistan ou encore la crise climatique, selon Moscou.Â
Le prÃ©sident Biden a d'ailleurs rÃ©affirmÃ© vouloir "travailler" avec les Russes "quand c'est dans notre intÃ©rÃªt commun".Â
Mais la Maison Blanche a Ã©galement insistÃ© sur le fait que son locataire n'allait pas pour autant "taire ses inquiÃ©tudes au sujet de ce qu'il considÃ¨re Ãªtre des actes nÃ©fastes".Â

ami:document.ami:content:
DUBLIN, April 1, 2021 /PRNewswire/ -- The "Waste To Energy (WTE) - Global Market Trajectory & Analytics" report has been added to ResearchAndMarkets.com's offering.
Global Waste To Energy (WTE) Market to Reach $48.5 Billion by 2027 Amid the COVID-19 crisis, the global market for Waste To Energy (WTE) estimated at US$ 32.3 Billion in the year 2020, is projected to reach a revised size of US$ 48.5 Billion by 2027, growing at a CAGR of 6% over the period 2020-2027.
Thermal, one of the segments analyzed in the report, is projected to record 5.8% CAGR and reach US$ 39.6 Billion by the end of the analysis period. After an early analysis of the business implications of the pandemic and its induced economic crisis, growth in the Biological segment is readjusted to a revised 6.9% CAGR for the next 7-year period. The U.S. Market is Estimated at $9.5 Billion, While China is Forecast to Grow at 5.6% CAGR The Waste To Energy (WTE) market in the U.S. is estimated at US$ 9.5 Billion in the year 2020. China, the world`s second largest economy, is forecast to reach a projected market size of US$ 8.5 Billion by the year 2027 trailing a CAGR of 5.6% over the analysis period 2020 to 2027.
Among the other noteworthy geographic markets are Japan and Canada, each forecast to grow at 5.6% and 4.8% respectively over the 2020-2027 period. Within Europe, Germany is forecast to grow at approximately 4.9% CAGR. Key Topics Covered: I. METHODOLOGY II. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 1. MARKET OVERVIEW
- Influencer Market Insights - World Market Trajectories - Impact of Covid-19 and a Looming Global Recession - Global Competitor Market Shares - Waste To Energy (WTE) Competitor Market Share Scenario Worldwide (in %): 2020E - Global Competitor Market Shares by Segment
2. FOCUS ON SELECT PLAYERSÂ Â (Total 36 Featured):
- Arrow Ecology Ltd. - Austrian Energy & Environment Group Gmbh - Babcock & Wilcox Volund A/S - Biogen Greenfinch (Biogen) - Bluefire Ethanol - Bta International Gmbh - Community Power Corporation (Cpc) - Constructions Industrielles De La Editerranee (Cnim) - Covanta Energy Corporation - Ecocorp
3. MARKET TRENDS & DRIVERS 4. GLOBAL MARKET PERSPECTIVE
- World Current & Future Analysis for Waste To Energy (WTE) by Geographic Region - USA, Canada, Japan, China, Europe, Asia-Pacific and Rest of World Markets - Independent Analysis of Annual Sales in US$ Million for Years 2020 through 2027 and % CAGR - World 7-Year Perspective for Waste To Energy (WTE) by Geographic Region - Percentage Breakdown of Value Sales for USA, Canada, Japan, China, Europe, Asia-Pacific and Rest of World Markets for Years 2020 & 2027 - World Current & Future Analysis for Thermal by Geographic Region - USA, Canada, Japan, China, Europe, Asia-Pacific and Rest of World Markets - Independent Analysis of Annual Sales in US$ Million for Years 2020 through 2027 and % CAGR - World 7-Year Perspective for Thermal by Geographic Region - Percentage Breakdown of Value Sales for USA, Canada, Japan, China, Europe, Asia-Pacific and Rest of World for Years 2020 & 2027 - World Current & Future Analysis for Biological by Geographic Region - USA, Canada, Japan, China, Europe, Asia-Pacific and Rest of World Markets - Independent Analysis of Annual Sales in US$ Million for Years 2020 through 2027 and % CAGR - World 7-Year Perspective for Biological by Geographic Region - Percentage Breakdown of Value Sales for USA, Canada, Japan, China, Europe, Asia-Pacific and Rest of World for Years 2020 & 2027

AFP, publiÃ© le lundi 15 fÃ©vrier 2021 Ã 17h45
La justice a suspendu lundi les dÃ©cisions du maire d'extrÃªme droite d'une ville du sud-ouest de la France qui avait dÃ©cidÃ© la rÃ©ouverture de quatre musÃ©es de sa ville, Ã l'encontre des directives sanitaires du gouvernement.
Maire de Perpignan, Louis Alliot avait dÃ©cidÃ© le 8 fÃ©vrier de rouvrir les quatre musÃ©es, sans attendre l'avis du gouvernement concernant ces lieux fermÃ©s depuis fin octobre pour lutter contre la pandÃ©mie.
Mais un juge de Montpellier (sud), s'appuyant sur un dÃ©cret gouvernemental du 29 octobre ordonnant la fermeture nationale des musÃ©es et lieux culturels, a suspendu l'exÃ©cution des dÃ©cisions prises par le maire qui ne peut "procÃ©der lui-mÃªme" Ã une telle ouverture, a prÃ©cisÃ© dans un communiquÃ© le tribunal administratif, saisi en rÃ©fÃ©rÃ© (procÃ©dure d'urgence) par le prÃ©fet des PyrÃ©nÃ©es-Orientales (sud). Â
Le maire de Perpignan "a mÃ©connu les dispositions" de l'article 45 du dÃ©cret du 29 octobre 2020 en autorisant l'ouverture des quatre musÃ©es.
"Nous regrettons cette dÃ©cision qui Ã©loignera encore un temps nos concitoyens durement Ã©prouvÃ©s par cette crise sanitaire", a rÃ©agi M. Aliot sur Twitter.
"La culture est un besoin essentiel qui ne demande qu'Ã s'exprimer", a t-il Ã©crit.Â

ami:document.ami:content:
(O) Online Shopping has by now become a part of everyday life for millions of people and it only keeps growing. We can expect 19% growth in eCommerce sales this year alone. However, online shopping hasnât even existed for that long (only 20 years or so). This creates huge challenges for designers. We are exploring a brand new frontier.
Every company has a unique business model. The products they sell, the size of their inventory, country, and shipping options all have an impact on the design requirements.
Designers working in eCommerce develop a certain skill-set that is unique. They must also understand marketing and development to a greater degree.
Letâs dig into what makes a great eCommerce designer.
1. Data analysis & balance As a designer with a marketing background, I have to mention the importance of data gathering & analysis. Many designers choose a pretty UI over functionality and user behavior. And for eCommerce, this is a fatal mistake.
In online shopping, the customer is king. You need to understand how your customer thinks, scrolls, reads, reacts or browses. You need to make it as easy as possible for your target customers to buy your products.
If you are redesigning an existing store, youâre in luck because you already have a wealth of information and existing customers that you can learn from. You have data from Google Analytics, which can help you with creating a buyer persona, understanding store audience, traffic sources, customer behavior, successful products, pain points, and conversion rates.
You can also use other tools to run session recording, heatmaps, sales analysis, create customer interviews/polls (if possible) and do competitor analysis. With session recording, you can actually look over the buyer's shoulder and watch their journeys.
PRO TIP: Itâs easy to get lost in the amount of unstructured data. You need to find a balance between data & common sense.
But what if you are designing a brand new store or you donât have any data?
In that case, you need to do some good competitor analysis. The simplest way to do this is to Google similar products to find competitors and get to know their sites well. Go through the site as a customer would, search for products, filter products, add to cart, check out their social media, etc. You will see what kind of challenges they faced and how they decided to solve them.
Look at both small and large brands. Many of the larger brands have the money and resources for thorough UX testing. Many of the smaller brands know their customer very well.
ââGood artists copy; great artists steal.ââ
â Picasso
2. Consider the need for speed Yes, youâve heard this many times. But for eCommerce (especially for growing mobile eCommerce), this is critical.
Googleâs mobile page speed study shows how the bounce rate rapidly grows when the website loads more than 3 seconds. And it affects sales â a 1-second delay in load time will cost you a 7% loss in conversions .
The design decisions you make are the basis for a quick loading speed. Developers can only do so much to reduce it. A fancy video background? 5 videos on a product page? This beautiful 3MB PNG image? Thereâs no way a developer can fix that. So keep this in mind when you design.
PRO TIP: Compress all your JPG images â e.g. using Squoosh . Use SVG for icons & illustrations, instead of PNG.
3. Mobile eCommerce (mCommerce) By 2021, mCommerce sales are expected to reach 54% of total eCommerce sales . Moreover, Google has been prioritizing mobile-friendly websites since 2018.
But mobile commerce is more than just eCommerce on a mobile screen. It is an evolution that involves not only your store, but also mobile payments, mobile banking, location-based services, augmented reality (like the Sephora Product Try-On app), mobile AI, chatbots, and more.
The major advantage of mCommerce is a better omnichannel experience for customers. And itâs accessible everywhere for everyone â not everyone has a computer.
So, what can you do to be ready for mCommerce as a designer?
- Page speed optimization (yes, again) - Mobile Navigation (e.g. bottom mobile menu, easy to access cart) - Big accessible buttons (for our fat and short fingers) - One-page checkouts and digital wallets (e.g. Amazon Pay, Apple Pay, PayPal One Touch) can seriously improve your mobile conversions.
4. Understanding the Customer Journey There are 5 main types of eCommerce shoppers . Understanding their differences can help you deliver a better experience for all of them:
- Product focused: They know exactly what they want and they want it quickly. Itâs important to provide them with a great search experience, access to previously purchased items, smart filters (to help find products faster) and a fast checkout that has all the information pre-filled. - Browsers: These are the more relaxed buyers â they browse different online stores, looking for trends, future purchases, inspiration or are just killing time. Top selling products, popular products, suggested products, new products, or the ability to share products are the most crucial features to convert them into buyers. - Researchers: They are in the early funnel stage, they collect information about products & prices, reading product and brand reviews. To turn them into buyers you have to win their trust, provide social proof, have a detailed product description & high-res zoom-on-hover images, easy-to-edit shopping carts, and a good wishlist. - Bargain hunters: They hunt for the best deal possible. Whatâs important for them is to find prices quickly and with no hidden costs. And they want to see how much they save on sales, coupons or special offers. Show them the numbers, quickly. - One-time shoppers: They can play any of the roles above but we need to remember that they have a one-time need. What is critical for this type? They hate long registrations. Your journey should give them clear navigation, product description, company information (like shipping and FAQ), and most importantly â checkout without registration.
5. Simplicity You donât need to reinvent the wheel. If something works well, donât add unnecessary elements or decorations. eCommerce is not the right place for showing off your graphic design skills.
ââGood design involves as little design as possible.ââ
â Dieter Rams
I use a simple rule to avoid useless elements. Just answer this quick question in 5â10 words: ââHow will it help get more sales?ââ.
PRO TIP: Checking out bigger & more successful competitors can be a great way of seeing whatâs necessary and what isnât. They have more data, traffic, experience, and resources to analyze, so they most likely take data-driven decisions.
6. Appreciate your customers time You know that feeling when you canât find shipping options? Or the button leads you to an unexpected page? Or you had no idea how many steps the registration would take? Do you remember how frustrated, lost or even angry you were?
We have so little time in this world, our day is planned down to the minute. Customers deserve to know how much time the process of purchasing the product will take, how much it will cost, or what shipping options they have.
Itâs critical to appreciate your customerâs time when you are designing their experience. Here are some ways to do that:
- Use progress indicators (for checkout, registration) - Use clear & relevant Call To Actions (CTAs) - Make sure the website architecture & links are clear e.g. example.com/category/product - Design intuitive navigation, especially on mobile - Make buying process information (like Shipping, Returns, FAQ) easy to find - Highlight the product availability (itâs so sad to finally realize the product you choose is out of stock) - Filters are essential for stores with 100+ products (e.g. I want to buy a red dress, donât make me scroll 5 pages of black dresses) - Good photography (even the best design looks bad with low-quality images) and zoom (I want to see it really close-up) - Gamification (a great example â Chillys Bottles Personalizer . I lost 10 minutes, just applying different bottle designs).
7. Test, analyze, and test again What have I learned so far from my marketing & design experience? There are no absolute rules. Yes, you can follow all the possible best practices, but your audience is unique, and requires a unique experience. What can you do? Test and analyze!
Low fidelity testing is the quickest way to solve problems and find the right solutions for your audience. Start with prototypes and discuss them with the store owners, your colleagues, friends, and trusted customers (if possible). The most important thing here is to separate good feedback from personal tastes.
PRO TIP: For small stores with unique products, store owners know their audience pretty well. And they can be a good advocate for their customers. So, itâs important to listen to their opinion and business goals.
If you are working on improving an existing store, you need to understand how to choose the right key performance indicators (KPIs) to track & analyze your changes. The essentials are:
- Sales Growth: Total sales and sales per channel during different seasons, months, years. - Conversion rates: Mainly visitors to sales, abandoned carts, conversion rate by marketing channel. - Customer acquisition cost (CAC): How much does it cost to attract one customer, and CAC by marketing channel. - Bounce Rate: The percentage of visitors who enter the site and then leave without viewing other pages. - Average order value
Changes in these KPIs are great indicators for a quick customer experience health-check.
For example, after adding a popup to the website we see the bounce rate has grown. After a small investigation (e.g. checking session recordings), we understand that itâs impossible to close it on mobile. After redesigning the mobile popup, the bounce rate improves. No polls or interviews needed, just KPIs.
The testing process can be iterative and involve really small changes (like font size, button color, content order). After each change, you should check the main KPIs & behavior changes. This approach of quick hypothesis testing is known as Growth Hacking .
Always remember that the customer journey is not finished even when the sale is complete. After that, there are still many steps to turn your buyers into brand advocates. Donât forget to send a great order summary with shipping details, update your customer on status changes, and bring them back to buy more.
Keep your eyes on the prize Designing for eCommerce is an exciting field to be in.
Making things beautiful is nice, but how do you really know if you are a good designer? Can you measure the value of your work?
In eCommerce, you can. The results of your design skills are reflected in the earnings of the store. This is what makes it so exciting, and I can honestly say, I love eCommerce design.
âDesign is not just what it looks like and feels like. Design is how it works.â
â Steve Jobs
This article was originally published on Dribbble .

TRANSPORTS -Â Victime de la fermeture des frontiÃ¨res franÃ§aises hors de lâUnion europÃ©enne et dâun effondrement du trafic aÃ©rien en pleine pandÃ©mie de Covid-19 , lâaÃ©roport dâOrly va fermer son terminal 4 lundi, jusquâÃ nouvel ordre.
Ce terminal sera fermÃ© dans la soirÃ©e, indique lundi Ã lâAFP une porte-parole de lâaÃ©roport dâOrly , confirmant une information du Parisien.
Les compagnies aÃ©riennes qui y opÃ©raient seront rÃ©orientÃ©es sur les deux terminaux dâOrly qui restent partiellement ouverts (2 et 3), prÃ©cise-t-elle, ajoutant que la date de rÃ©ouverture nâest pour le moment pas connue. ami:document.ami:content:
Photo by Mikey RamirezItâs hard to estimate design effort. Especially in a meeting full of expectant faces, waiting for you to drop a number. We designers get it wrong so many times, we end up adding big buffers just to be safe.
It sucks to get it wrong, but it also sucks to mislead.
We often hear, âDonât sweat it, knowing how to put up a confident estimate comes with years of experience.â Sureâ¦ But still, how do we account for uncertainty?
If youâre in a SaaS company focusing on agile product development, itâs common to have flexible deadlines for deliverables.
But not all projects have the same tolerance. Youâll find those needing coordination between multiple departments, have high revenue impact, that have a launch date set for that big bangâ¦ theyâre the ones that demand the most predictability.
So Product Designers, hereâs how to be less shitty at giving estimates: 1. How big is the Scope?The easiest way to gauge this is by the number of requirements. Keep in mind that itâs often the most vague (least scoped out) requirements that sneak in like a cat with a dead rat. Watch out for those!
2. How Complex is the work?If you have mapped out an ideal user journey, look back to it and ask: Does the MVP bypass steps in that journey to make it quicker to build? The more steps it overlooks, the higher chance you have of sacrificing the UX, and overcompensating on the UI. This adds complexity to the designs, which burdens the user.
If you donât have a user journey map to consult, this may not be the right stage to be creating delivery estimates. Ask for time to do some design discovery.
3. What are the Dependencies?Does your work rely on needing information from others? Is the solution dependant on decisions others need to make? What are your blockers?
4. What are the Expectations?Timing, quality, the depth of the solution, the fidelity of the design output (wireframes vs pixel-perfect mocks)â¦ If the stakes are high for the project to succeed, youâll need to be testing and validating a whole lot more before building, meaning a longer design process. If the impact of the work is relatively low, or the work is experimental, thereâs a higher tolerance for learning and iterating after shipping.
5. What Skills are required? Whether youâre a team of one, or youâll be assigning the task to another designer â if there is a learning curve, youâll need to factor in that time. E.g. If your designers have little experience creating personas, think about their speed to learn before they can apply those skills to the task.
Next time youâre invited to a meeting, and know youâll need to provide an estimate, ask yourself these 5 questions.
If you find yourself ambushed in a hallway, or quizzed over the groan of a coffee grinder, asking them these questions can reset expectations and give you time for a considered answer.
Of course, itâs only when youâre squinting at the details, that the full scale of the problem reveals itself. Until then, apply these tips and hopefully youâll land not too far from the moon!
Jade TSP
Leading design @ TransferWise. Previously at Vend, and Vital. Fascinated about the art and science in design.

ami:document.ami:content:
Each weekend, I wake up, shower, and meander over to one of a handful of coffee shops in my neighborhood to write. I take only a blue-ink Bic Cristal pen and a notebook. At work, though, I use an array of apps and software to draft, revise, share, and hand off copy to my colleagues. Iâm probably not doing these things in the most efficient way possible, however. I canât help but wonder (see what I did there?)âwhat tools do other writers use when drafting copy for web, mobile, and TV?
Hereâs a brief rundown of things I use on the regular to write and share product and marketing copy:
Google Docs Ever since suggested edits (Googleâs version of âtracked changesâ) made their debut, my team has used Google Docs exclusively for writing and editing copy. Because everyone at Vimeo has an enterprise account, weâre able to securely share docs with anyone at the company. While I donât love that we have to grant edit access to someone to allow them to suggest changes, this method is still far better than the save + send + download + edit + save again + send back method we were stuck with before. We create shared folders for projects in which we house all related documentsâthis could be anything from meeting notes, messaging/positioning docs, launch blog post drafts and social copy, to the actual copy deck that we pass to the designers and developers. This way, itâs easy to find and share docs for any given projects, which makes it easier for us to maintain consistency between the product and marketing copy. Itâs also super simple for us to archive these once we close out the project.
Zeplin More recently, our design teams across the organization have adopted Zeplin as a means of storing and sharing comps, and passing them off to dev once theyâre finalized. The Zeplin files act as a âsource of truthâ for the entire design/build team, including us writers. This is also a good way for us to keep tabs on any design changes that come through late in the product development cycle. I will often cruise through and make sure no additional copy has been added. If I see a new string, I can comment directly on the design with questions, or the correct wording.
InVisionNow that we use Zeplin to store designs, we havenât been relying on InVision as much for circulating comps to stakeholders. Nor am I reviewing mocks and giving copy feedback via InVision comments as often as I used to. We still use the service to create interactive prototypes, however. Sometimes, our designers create these to help them gather internal feedback but more often than not, we use them for user testing sessions. InVision prototypes are a great way to give users a feel for the new features and interactions (and copy) youâre developing without investing a ton of time and effort building something that youâre not 100% sure will be effective (and when are you ever that sure???).
Github So, Iâm a writer. Not a developer. So why am I in Github ? For the same reason all the designers areâweâre often chiming in on tickets to answer questions coming from our product team or our developers. Often, I end up drafting error message strings, etc. directly in a ticket. I also create tickets occasionally. If, as Iâm cruising through our site or one of our apps, I discover a string that I did not write, or one thatâs been implemented incorrectly in production, I will ticket the error in Github and assign it to the appropriate developer. Each week, I go back through the issues Iâve created and follow up with people until theyâre resolved. As UX writers, weâre often the only people keeping tabs on things like proper capitalization, or the separation of âlogâ and âin.â For this reason, itâs often on us to call out the error, and make sure it gets fixed. If you donât have access to Github (or Confluence, or whatever system your engineers use), you should definitely ask for an account.
Sketch Again, Iâm a writer. Not a designer. But Iâm constantly working with designers to solve a problem for our users, and to write copy for our various interfaces and interactions. In many cases, I have to download Sketch files to review designs (our designers are now exporting Sketch files directly to Zeplin, rather than constantly saving out PNGs). Sketch is also extremely fun to use, and has way less of a learning curve than Photoshop or Illustrator. Itâs easy to create barebones mockups to convey ideas I have for a particular layout or flowâin fact, now I only use Sketch for this instead of Balsamiq.
Thesaurus.com For middle-school children attempting to âsmartenâ up their papers by cramming them with long, highfalutin vocabulary, a thesaurus can be a dangerous thing. But for a professional writer, itâs an essential tool. I donât turn to a thesaurus as a brain replacement, but rather, as a brainstorming tool. When Iâm working on a naming project, for instance, I often need to stare at long lists of words simply to remember what else is out thereâoften, Iâll see a word on thesaurus.com that reminds me of the actual word I was looking for in the first place. This isnât cheating, itâs simply what happens when youâre one of a few writers at your company and youâre lacking someone (or something) to bounce ideas off of.
Grammar Girl Achieving proper syntax, impeccable punctuation, and perfect hyphenation is extremely difficult, even for the most experienced word nerds among us. There are thousands of rules we must memorize and sometimes, we make mistakes. It happens. But for experienced writers and editors, weâre more often than not attune to when we arenât quite sure about something, grammatically speaking. In these moments of uncertainty, just look it up. I often Google grammar rules to double-check myself, even when Iâve known for decades that you should hyphenate 12-year-old, but not âshe was 12 years old.â Grammar Girl is my favorite online go-to (because I try not to lug my Garnerâs Modern American Usage onto the subway). The Chicago Manual of Style, Purdue Owl, and even random NY Times articles are other resources I reference regularly, and free of guilt.
Moat.com This one applies more to marketing and communications copywriters than to UX writers, but if youâre ever looking for advertising inspiration from other brands or companies, Moat is an A+ resource. Type in the name of a brand you admire, or a competitor, and voilÃ âall of their current and past banner advertisements will appear before your eyes.
Siteinspire.comWhen Iâm looking for landing page inspirationâeither for copy or designâI turn to a number of different sources. Siteinspire.com , though, is my favorite, by far. Itâs simple to browse, and all of the sites it showcases are of a higher caliber than those on One Page Love , and others.
Really Good Emails I never thought Iâd say this, but Iâm sort of a sucker for everything MailChimp creates, at least in terms of resources for writers. If you ever want to compare your transactional, reengagement, onboarding, welcome, or marketing emails to that of other brands, take a spin through the different categories at reallygoodemails.com . (Iâm mean, the name aloneâ¦)
Moz If youâve ever written page tags and descriptions (which you should be doing, if youâre writing copy for new features and landing pages), youâve likely Googled âseo best practices.â Moz has some of the easiest-to-follow explanations Iâve found to-date. In addition to their help articles, they also regularly post to their blog. While not all of their writing will appeal to the average UX writer, it is helpful to know, at least, things like ideal character counts, and whether your brand name should come at the beginning or end of a title tag.
Smartling In addition to writing copy for web, mobile, and TV in English, I also guide our in-house and Smartling translators. At Vimeo, I wrote both a brief set of style guidelines specific to translation, and also put together a glossary of Vimeo-specific terms, and a chart that defines when we do and not capitalize words, and when we should and should not translate proper nouns (e.g., the names of products like Vimeo PRO). All of these documents are housed in Smartling. And once we submit a set of strings for translation, I hop into Smartling and respond to translator comments to clarify any points of confusion. At some companies, the developers submitting the strings might be responsible for this, but it makes more sense for us, the writers, to be explaining the tone and intention behind the words, as well as the context.
Have other tools to add to this list? Leave a comment, please. For less-tactical best-practice-type resources, take a look at these links .

Zeplin More recently, our design teams across the organization have adopted Zeplin as a means of storing and sharing comps, and passing them off to dev once theyâre finalized. Celles-ci lui reprochent d'exploiterÂ les droits et les donnÃ©es des utilisateurs, souvent trÃ¨s jeunes. La Commission europÃ©enne sera saisie, afin que soit lancÃ©e une enquÃªte sur les pratiques de cette application trÃ¨s populaire de partage de vidÃ©os, indique mardi 16Â fÃ©vrier l'association franÃ§aise UFC-Que Choisir dans un communiquÃ©.
Entre guerre commerciale opposant PÃ©kin Ã Washington, et faits divers, la populaire application de vidÃ©os lÃ©gÃ¨res est rÃ©guliÃ¨rement pointÃ©e du doigt Ã travers le monde. TikTok avait restreint mi-janvier les paramÃ¨tres de confidentialitÃ© de ses utilisateurs Ã¢gÃ©s deÂ 13Â Ã 15Â ans quelques jours aprÃ¨s que des observateurs ont accusÃ© son algorithme de favoriser l'accÃ¨s Ã des vidÃ©os sexualisÃ©es mettant en scÃ¨ne des mineurs. Les autoritÃ©s italiennes avaient quant Ã elles bloquÃ© fin janvier l'accÃ¨s du rÃ©seau aux utilisateurs dont l'Ã¢ge n'est pas garanti, aprÃ¨s la mort d'une fillette de 10Â ans en Sicile qui participait au Â«Â jeu du foulardÂ Â» sur le rÃ©seau social.
Des pratiques Â«Â dÃ©testablesÂ Â» L'UFC-Que Choisir estime que le rÃ©seau social Â«Â ne rÃ©ussit pasÂ Â» Ã protÃ©ger les jeunes et cite des manquements dans la protection contre la publicitÃ© cachÃ©e et les contenus Â«Â potentiellement dangereuxÂ Â». De plus, la plateforme accepte les inscriptions Ã partir de 13Â ans, pourtant 45Â % des enfants sous cet Ã¢ge ont indiquÃ© utiliser l'application en France , affirme Que Choisir. L'UFC dÃ©nonce Ã©galement Â«Â le systÃ¨me trompeurÂ Â» des Â«Â cadeaux virtuelsÂ Â» visant Ã rÃ©compenser les vidÃ©os prÃ©fÃ©rÃ©es des internautes. TikTok Â«Â met tout en Åuvre pour que l'utilisateur oublie qu'il s'agit d'argent rÃ©elÂ Â», affirme l'UFC, qualifiant ces pratiques de Â«Â dÃ©testablesÂ Â».

L'association estime aussi que les donnÃ©es des utilisateurs sont Â«Â surexploitÃ©esÂ Â», Â«Â contrairement aux obligations des RGPDÂ Â», le rÃ¨glement qui garantit aux usagers certains droits sur leurs donnÃ©es. Â«Â TrÃ¨s concrÃ¨tement, TikTok se donne le droit de faire ce qu'il veut des vidÃ©os publiÃ©esÂ : les utiliser, les modifier, les reproduire sans que les utilisateurs n'aient leur mot Ã direÂ Â», affirme encore Que Choisir.

ami:document.ami:content:
Image from Absurd Design This text is not only for you, dear reader. It is also for me and to the future Designer I intend to be in the next years. Because all the following topics are my learning through my first year working like a Product Designer, but I know that I have to always keep them in mind. In fact, Iâm still learning to put them in practice, so I promise to return here always and read again, to remember and keep improving. So letâs go to the topics!
Ask about everything â Donât be afraid of being critique There is a technique in UX Research called â5 Whysâ which helps us get to the root cause of a problem quickly or to explore the usersâ answers in interviews or testings, for example. Basically you can use this technique asking 5 times âwhyâ a defined problem is occurring.
So this technique is good to understand not only userâs problems, but also to understand the business priorities. When I say âask about everythingâ it means asking your stakeholders too. Every time someone come and say we have to work on something, ask âwhysâ:
- Why is it so important? Do we really have to do it? - Why are the users being impact? What is the impact? Who are these users? - Why is it the priority? Which data support this priority?
There are two words that every designer needs to be comfortable saying: âwhyâ and âno.â With every project that crosses your desk, you need to ask âWhy are we doing this?â Asking that question is part of the job. âBecause I am telling you to,â is not an acceptable answer, and if thereâs no answer beyond that, you need to reply with âno.â â Mike Monteiro, âDear Designer: Your First Job â.
One year ago I was afraid of being âtoo critiqueâ asking too many âwhysâ. But instead I was encouraged to do so, because it is part of my job: to understand the business and the real problem. Here it comes the second topicâ¦
Study Design and really understand about the business Itâs important to be confident when asking so many âwhyâsâ. In order to increase your confidence itâs necessary trying to really understand the core business of your company. Also how Design can help the company solve problems and grow.
Itâs very important to have strong arguments so you can defend your ideas and the importance of researching something before hand. You will face people who donât see value in the Design process, so the more you know about it and its business impact, the better you can explain and defend your work in the company.
But our work is not only defending the âdesign processâ point of view. Being a defender of this question does not mean imposing our opinion, quite the opposite. It means you have to act like a facilitator sometimesâ¦
Designer is a facilitator Iâm not the owner of the ideas and Iâm not the only person who knows what is right or wrong about an experience. Iâm a facilitator and my work is helping guide my team understand the users and also share their ideas about what we have to do. My job is search for data to base our decisions. All design decisions should be based on research and data, not on what I think.
Our work is essentially collaborative and to improve this sense of collaboration in your workplaceâ¦
Keep practicing constant feedback Here in this topic it doesnât matter if youâre a designer or not. Our evolution depends on feedback so be open, listen and give feedback to people who work with you. Try keeping feedback as a constant practice between people on your team, because itâs a great way you can progress together.
Seniority is about a behavior â Run from âimpostor syndromeâ Being a âjunior designerâ doesnât mean you have to accept orders only. You can assume some responsibilities by asking more questions. Be curious about everything: the product, the business, what people around you do at their routine, who are these people, what are our purpose and so on.
Besides that, donât go and think you are in the wrong place when you donât know what to do. Youâre not an impostor. Not knowing about how to act or what to do in some situations is not an exclusive âjunior designerâ issue. After all, being a senior one doesnât guarantee knowing everything, doesnât it?
Getting better as a designer means valuing curiosity more than mastery and embracing what you donât know more than fearing it. â Mike Monteiro, Dear Designer: How You Can Tell Youâre Getting Better .
Design less and always write Last but not least, this topic is something that I took from this text of Jon Moore: âThe Ultimate Guide to Becoming a Great Designer (Part 3 of 3) â. I really recommend reading all three parts of it.
When we talk about being a designer, everyone will think about interfaces first. But itâs not about it at all. Interfaces are important but before them itâs essential to really understand the problem we are trying to solve, what impact we want to make and how it can help the businessâ goals. So itâs about planning, strategies, facilitating ideas and solving problems â with or without interfaces. So thinking that way we shouldnât âonly designâ (literally focused on interfaces). We should go beyond that.
Everything should be documented. First, because itâs really important to share with everyone on your company. So write your process, organize ideas, donât lose data from research. Second, writing is also important to share our learnings with the Design community. By showing our work we can help others while also receiving help from someone who can see improvements, which we were not seeing.
And yes, you do not need to be a senior designer to write about something. Moore wrote:
âCandidly, I felt like a bit of an imposter the first time I wrote about design. Who was I to be waxing poetic about topics my manager had just taught me days before? I didnât feel like I deserved an audience because I didnât have the âcredentialsâ to back up my philosophies.
What Iâve discovered about writing is that when you first put pen to paper, youâre writing for yourself. Itâs not about your audience, itâs not about claps, and itâs not about landing a book deal.
Writing about design is about reflecting on your beliefs, your technique, and your processâ. â Jon Moore: âThe Ultimate Guide to Becoming a Great Designer (Part 3 of 3) â

But our work is not only defending the âdesign processâ point of view. Seniority is about a behavior â Run from âimpostor syndromeâ Being a âjunior designerâ doesnât mean you have to accept orders only. Not knowing about how to act or what to do in some situations is not an exclusive âjunior designerâ issue.

But our work is not only defending the âdesign processâ point of view.
